üåç The race to dominate A.I. technology has emerged as a new form of tech war, with the United States and China at the forefront, each developing their distinct tech sectors.
üõ¢Ô∏è Data's pivotal role in enhancing A.I. performance likened to oil, positioning China as a leader due to its vast data resources.
üéÆ The ancient Chinese game of Go spotlighted as a milestone, where Google's AlphaGo defeating world champion Lee Sedol marked A.I.'s potential to surpass human intelligence and creativity.
üß† Introduction of deep learning in A.I., mimicking human neural networks, demonstrated publicly through AlphaGo, highlighting A.I.'s ability to learn and innovate beyond human capabilities.
üèÜ AlphaGo's victory over Lee Sedol underscored as a pivotal moment, awakening the global community to A.I.'s advancements and its future commercial implications.
üöÄ China's strategic response to AlphaGo's success, embarking on an aggressive A.I. development plan aiming to lead the world by 2030.
üìà Rapid evolution and implementation of A.I. in China, fueled by an abundance of data, leading to significant advancements and the creation of numerous A.I. "unicorns."
üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Advancements in A.I. leading to innovative applications in China, such as autonomous vehicles and facial recognition, while raising concerns about privacy and the ethical use of A.I.
üßä The concept of deep learning involves machines acquiring knowledge from data and examples, similar to how children learn by interacting with the world.
üïπÔ∏è DeepMind's A.I. program demonstrated its learning capability by mastering the Atari game Breakout, eventually outperforming human players and discovering creative strategies.
üí° Amy Webb suggests A.I. could lead to innovative solutions for challenges like climate change and incurable diseases by enhancing human creativity.
üè• A.I. technologies are advancing medical diagnoses, exemplified by Massachusetts General Hospital's use of deep learning to predict breast cancer earlier than traditional methods.
üöö The advancement of autonomous trucks highlights A.I.'s potential to revolutionize industries but also raises concerns about job displacement and economic impacts on workers.
ü§ñ A.I.'s influence is likened to the impact of the Industrial Revolution, signifying a major shift in overcoming the limitations of human minds.
üìà Kai-Fu Lee acknowledges A.I.'s potential to disrupt both blue-collar and white-collar jobs, highlighting the need for societal preparation and adaptation.
üö® Despite optimism in the tech community, there's growing concern about A.I.'s broader implications on employment, with debates on how to mitigate negative effects on the workforce.
üö® Uighurs in Xinjiang face extreme surveillance and repression, with technologies that monitor and control every aspect of their lives, serving as a model for other authoritarian regimes.
üåç China's Belt and Road Initiative aims to extend its technological and political influence worldwide, offering infrastructure and surveillance technology to developing nations.
üì° Huawei's leadership in 5G technology and the international concern over its ties to the Chinese government highlight global tensions over technology and security.
üåê The potential split between a Chinese and an American tech sector suggests a future where countries must align with one or the other, reminiscent of Cold War alignments.
üõ§Ô∏è The Belt and Road Initiative's infrastructure projects around the world serve as a vehicle for spreading Chinese technology and increasing political leverage.
üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è The use of Chinese surveillance technology in various countries indicates a growing global footprint of China's approach to governance and control.
üé≠ Amidst rising power, China's tech giants are racing to develop their own technologies in response to American restrictions, underscoring the decoupling of U.S. and Chinese tech sectors.
ü§ñ The documentary concludes with reflections on the dual potential of AI for societal good and authoritarian control, emphasizing the need for careful strategy and global cooperation to harness AI's power responsibly.

The term AI has become a catch all that includes LLM's like chat GPT as well as schemes like machine learning and so called neural networks of computers.  Despite being optimistically named by their creators these setups are still just fancy calculators, albeit very powerful calculators running at incomprehensible speeds,  which while obviously artificial are not in any way intelligent as the word is normally understood.  The AI doomsday scenarios often talked about where machines takeover or attack humanity are all predicated on developing machines with actual intelligence, I.e. the ability to think independently and make decisions without human input.  This doesn't exist and most likely never will, computers are still just fancy calculators doing what we tell them, the only ideas involved all come from human beings.  The danger is not the fancy calculators themselves rather it's  the humans who control them we need to keep an eye on, worrying about actual artificial intelligence with a mind of its own attacking us is a fun idea for Hollywood scriptwriters but can also be a distraction or a red herring to shift focus away from the actual threats posed by surveilence capitalism running amok

Fifty years ago I thought that someday - maybe in 500 years - AI would give us a clear and useful definition of intelligence. And this would revolutionize human life. Yes, it would give us some real neat gadgets and it might also give us some dangerous gadgets, but the tech would be secondary. The singularity would be the idea. Essentially I was hoping that AI would someday do what dumb computers did in the 20th century.

Computers were invented to solve differential equations numerically. Solving differential equations numerically is important. Climate models do it. Almost all computer models do it. Spaceship guidance computers do it. But solving differential equations is not a pressing need for most people.

If computers were JUST machines to solve differernial equations numerically, the human race could make do with a few thousand of the things. If we remember that every embedded system is also a computer, we have more computers than human beings. Earth contains chips, insects and a modest dash of human clay.

Computers do some of everything. When you load a different program, your computer becomes in essence a different machine. Computers evolved from hyper-specialized math machines to super-generalized information machines for one simple reason - we know what information is. We REALLY know.

In 1900 the phrase "quantity of information" was as vague and useless as "quantity of virtue". But not today. Today the phrase "a bit of information" is about as wispy as "a pound of butter". This means we can see the information aspect of everything. And computerize everything.

In the seventies, when I was young and still believed young things, I thought that AI would make it two for two. Define "intelligence" and use that knowledge. And give the world that knowledge. I also thought it would take a few centuries. And that was the problem.

To do AI right... AI powered by insight... would take a long, long time. Unfortunately, you can make AI powered by sleaze.

Sleaze AI erases the difference between "intelligence" and "intelligent behavior". Sleaze AI says, "I have this black box. It does whatever. I don't know what it does actually, but customers approve. Customers say it acts real smart. Therefore, it is real smart." Intelligence is no longer something in the brainbox. It's something in the market. It is a marketing term.
The sad thing is that it would actually be incredibly useful to have surveillance systems and data collection if we collected & used it ethically. However, it has been ruined by corporate greed.
We (US) taught them.

--------------------------------
A.I. is becoming a pivotal force in our world
- A.I. is being developed rapidly in China and the US
- A.I. has the potential to increase productivity but also threaten jobs
- A.I. is being used for corporate surveillance and poses a threat to democracy
- The game of Go signaled a new era for A.I.
- A.I. has the potential to deepen inequality and divide the world into A.I. superpowers

China leads the world in AI thanks to a new generation of ambitious techs and venture capitalists.
- China recognized AI as critical for the future, catching up with foreign companies and investing in its development.
- China's progress in AI implementation in just 2.5 years is hard to believe, with about 17-18 billion-dollar companies in AI today.
- Chinese universities produce ambitious young techs competing for new ideas, financed by a new cadre of Chinese venture capitalists.
- China's form of entrepreneurship is described as tenacious, very fast, winner-take-all, and has an incredible work ethic.

China's social-credit system is powerful and troublesome
- Experimenting with social-credit system in Shanghai
- China aims to lead the world in AI by 2030
- Self-driving trucks could be ten times safer than human drivers

Deep learning has changed the map and is now used in almost every sector of society.
- Computers acquire knowledge by themselves from data and examples.
- Machines help us be more creative and find solutions to urgent problems.
- Deep learning can predict early-stage conditions in breast cancer.

Truck drivers are worried about automation due to rising inequality in wages.
- Truckers like Shawn and Hope Cumbee face high expenses and breakdowns that eat into their profits.
- Companies like Embark are already operating driverless trucks on the interstate.

A.I. could threaten about 50% of jobs in the next 15 years
- A.I. is not close to displacing humans yet
- People in Silicon Valley have different opinions on the impact of A.I.
- Kai-Fu Lee is frank about the downside of A.I.

Automation is the silent job killer, lowering the standard of living.
- Offshoring is responsible for only 20% of job loss.
- Productivity growth is responsible for most of the job loss.
- Automation leads to increased productivity but also results in job loss.
- The decline in standard of living has been between 10% to 15% in the last 15 years.

Automation and A.I. are rapidly changing the job market, disproportionately affecting women and those in low-paying jobs.
- Many routine and information-processing jobs, such as cashiers and clerical staff, are at high risk of automation.
- Without economic stability and access to training, workers are struggling to adapt to the changing job market.

We are in a new phase of the economy called surveillance capitalism.
- Surveillance capitalism claims private human experience as a source of raw material.
- Google began using digital traces of users' behavior to predict their interests and make money.

Google and Facebook use behavioral prediction to make money
- Google kept their revenue secret until their IPO in 2004, where it was revealed that their revenue had increased by 3,590% between 2000 and 2004
- Facebook and Google collect data from free services and use it for prediction models, which has raised concerns about privacy and the corporate surveillance state

California residents will have the right to know and control their digital data
- Proposed California ballot initiative to give consumers control of their digital data worth $4 million
- New law passed in California will give residents the right to know what personal information tech companies have, and the right to say no to selling it

Artificial intelligence and surveillance technology are becoming increasingly pervasive and opaque in everyday life.
- The use of AI in hiring processes and risk assessment algorithms in the criminal justice system are often hidden from individuals.
- In authoritarian states like China, AI and surveillance technology are being used to monitor and control citizens to an alarming degree, with reports of human rights abuses and political re-education camps for ethnic minorities.

The world is dominated by just two AI superpowers
- The US fears Huawei's 5G equipment may have back-door access to Chinese government
- Chinese tech companies like Megvii have difficulty accessing American technology
- The idea of engagement between China and the US is coming under question
- If China and the US are fundamentally antagonistic to each other, then we're in a completely different world

A.I. has the potential to be used for good and evil, and governments need to find a balance
- A.I. is a technology that can be used for good and evil.
- Governments need to limit themselves in using A.I. to maintain a safe environment without encroaching on individual rights and privacies.
- Every country will be tempted to use A.I. beyond the limits that citizens would like.
- Democracy is threatened by the progress of A.I. unless we increase the collective wisdom to deal with the increased power.
- The stakes are high, and we should not take these concerns lightly.

01:10:05 üíº Surveillance capitalism claims private human experiences as raw material for predicting human behavior, creating a new business model.

Go is a bad system to measure AI success. Randomness is too powerful for a comptuer to cope with. There are fewer and fewer moves as the game continues. Chess and games like starcraft are easier for an AI to succede in because there are fewer moves to make at the start. It can have an easy handle on how to gain early advantages responding to the standard moves.  The randomness of go would allow a spiteful player to make random or suboptimal moves and open up weaknesses/descision processes in the AI.

Everything in this is an absolute horror. The game of Go has applications to warfare: watch as generals begin relying on AI advisors to strike in places and with weapons that would never have been countenanced before. The "social credit" programs in China or fears in the US of how AI will take over skilled white-collar jobs (while blue-collar jobs don't pay enough to live on) are only the obvious form of how AI exacerbates inequality. For example, politial or economic dissidents, or even just people with disabilities that cause them to behave in ways which don't conform with social norms will end up locked out (in some cases, physically) from access to goods, services and resources and marginalized,

Note that in many cases cashiers and delivery drivers have already been removed from Chinese cities, as pointed out in the segment showing off how Chinese people bypassed credit cards and now pay for goods in stores without cashiers with facial recognition. But that's not freeing people to take on higher-paying jobs, or to work fewer hours and enjoy themselves more: that's never how these disruptions work. It's simply creating a bigger underclass of people who are more willing to do menial work for extremely low pay just to survive, and no Triangle Fire to draw attention to the problem.

This is also a burgeoning environmental disaster, right along with cryptocurrency. Both crypto and AI require mountains of data in order to operate on servers that run 24/7, and the ever-increasing mountains of data need to be stored on servers that also run 24/7. The entire Columbia River Basin isn't enough anymore for the power consumption required for Bitcoin alone (part of why other cryptocurrencies have sprouted like weeds). The sheer amount of energy necessary to maintain this renders it unsustainable, most especially in the era of climate change already being driven by anthropogenic climate warming. (Those server farms require intense air conditioning to keep the servers running, which is also energy-intensive in its own right and makes each server farm its own dedicated heat island capable of altering the local climate expression around it the same way cities do.) Most of China's electricity is still generated by coal-fired power plants, though a slightly bigger percentage than in previous years is now coming from hydro. The IPCC put out a damning report less than a month ago, telling us in no uncertain terms that the world needs drastic cuts in emissions, we needed them yesterday, and that without them we are very likely to overshoot the 2'C target of the Paris Accords within the decade, leading to major sea level rise and rainfall disruptions worldwide. China has put more than 40 dams on the barely 200 miles or so of the Upper Mekong River that flows through its country in order to support the country's water consumption, energy generation - and yes, political pressure on Vietnam, which China once conquered centuries ago and still regards as its colonial possession, putting the entire Mekong ecosystem in danger of collapse and that's only part of what it's doing to the water supplies in Asia as it pursues AI technology. Noam Chomsky, Professor Emeritus at MIT, derides AI as "expensive, high-tech plagiarism" with "no scientific value at all" but dangerous nonetheless.

Never forget that these are private, for-profit corporations driving the development of AI. They are billed as "large language models" but they don't actually teach us anything about the development of language at all. The massive investments of energy and money going into AI are being made, not because the boards of the global tech giants suddenly began to get a conscience or altruistically decided to do something for the benefit of mankind, but because they run businesses and they expect a profit for their shareholders that will dwarf that investment many times over - all from the data that they get from you for free. Most places in the US still do not have comprehensive legislation governing the collection or use of your digital data by private companies. Any benefit you see from this will be by accident, you will not be compensated otherwise for your data that fed the machines, and they will claw it back from you at the first opportunity. This shouldn't be allowed to continue, and it's going to take mass tragedy and mass horror before enough outrage comes together worldwide to curtail the infringement of AI (and the corporations behind it) upon the rights of human beings.

I'm a tech enthusiast and think AI is very interesting but Google AI did not win that game of Go just like IBMs computer in the 80's or 90's never beat a grand-master at Chess. Why? Frankly I'm not sure why nobody is picking up on this but these computers have handicaps. Here's what I mean...

If a skilled golfer like Tiger Woods is challenged to a golf game but is forced to use a plastic wiffle bat designed for children as his only club, then I could probably beat Tiger Woods. Just like a world champion at Go has to use their brain for countless other things other than playing a game. Our brains are doing countless things a second, many of which we barely understand or take for granted and things that a computer doesn't have to do. For some examples...

Our brains are constantly regulating our heart beat and temperature to keep us alive. Our brains are also constantly managing our immune system with white blood cells and a number of other evolutionary traits that have taken millions of years to develop from species to species. Likewise our brains have to manage our emotions with dopamine and a long list of things I don't understand and I doubt the worlds greatest doctors fully understand. This gets into questions of consciousness or even spirituality if you believe in that sort of thing.

Long story short, a computer isn't constantly being distracted by other essential responsibilities. This is a handicap so in other words, these games are fixed. Like giving a bad chess player 30 minutes to make as many moves as they want against a chess master without them being ably to move their pieces but it's even worse than that actually.

As complex as they have become computers are still nowhere near as complex as human beings. Even single molecules of human DNA alone are so complex that they...

"store up to 215 petabytes, or 215 million gigabytes, of data in a single doubled stranded molecule"

We're talking about ONE molecule and good luck counting the amount of total DNA molecules in a human, you need a microscope just to see single cells in the body which contain our DNA. So hands down, we're more complex and advanced than ANY computer. It's more data and complexity than all the worlds computers combined and it isn't remotely close. Imagine if all of that data and processing power was solely dedicated to playing Go or Chess. I can guarantee you that these games would end a lot differently. Case closed

I'm 79. -- A major lobbying concern during the development of the US Interstate System long ago was "Highway Hypnosis".
I recall TV news depicting a drowsy truck driver about to fall asleep at the wheel during long nights on long straight stretches.

Armchair authorities saw the problem as lack of brain stimulation due to the monotony.
Their solution was winding roads through nice surroundings.
That was our first Interstate -- the Pennsylvanian Pike -- and the Merritt Parkway (CT).

Winding roads would consume more concrete, carry more cars of steel & rubber while using more gasoline,
putting railroads in forced decline, favoring expanding airlines -- made possible by the immense amounts of concrete needed to expand the demand for airport runways and cities with tall buildings.
Gradually we recognized the need for more regulation of trucks, roads, loads and durations.

We've come a long way while dragging our heels with "Common Sense:
It became time for a little AI and a lot of big data.

But -
How can you apply AI to the human concerns of sympathy, empathy, and compassion?
Do you know the difference between them?

Here's a situation:
A man has fallen into a deep pit. He needs help.
Someone passes by, sees him, and says: I'm late for a meeting.
I have a long way to go, but I promise to tell the first person I see.
Someone will come. I'm really sorry. I must go -- and continues on. -- That's Sympathy.

Another person comes by and sees the man in the pit, clearly distressed.
He says: Oh, you poor lost soul, then jumps into the pit to comfort him -- as a friend.
Both are stuck --- That is compassion.
One person could climb on the shoulders of the other and escape, which raises an important choice -- Trust.

A third person passes by and sees a man in the pit.
He quickly looks for whatever he can find -- a rope, a vine, or stick, and pulls him from the pit. -- That is empathy.

What is the value of a life?
Read two poems --
Amantium Irae
and The Touch of the Master's Hand.

Going by just the rules, Go is easily not the most complex board game. There's a difference between the rules and their implications. But, even going by "number of possible moves" (which, as near as I can tell, means "number of possible scenarios (or combinations of where and when to place stones)" because Go only has two "moves", either place a stone or pass), I expect that the best you can say is that it is the most complex board game you've calculated the "number of possible moves" for. I doubt, just for one example, that it has more "possible moves" than some basketball court-sized, days long war-simulation miniatures games.

Also, part of what determines what humans figure out is how motivated they are to figure it out.

49:25 2013 Oxford Study 47% of Jobs at High Risk of being automated

51:25 Narrator: ‚ÄúThis day it‚Äôs the center for a Christmas food drive. Even in a growth economy, unemployment here is near 6%. Poverty in Saginaw is over 30%.

Worker: ‚ÄúOur factory has about 1.9 million square feet. Back in the 70s, that 1.9 million square feet had about 7,500 U.A.W. automotive workers making middle-class wages with decent benefits, and able to send their kids to college and do all the things that the middle-class family should be able to do. Our factory today, with automation, would probably be about 700 United Auto Workers. That‚Äôs a dramatic change.‚Äù




***52:55 Graph: Productivity and Median Household Income 1939-2017

Andrew McAfee: ‚ÄúIf you look at this graph of what‚Äôs been happening to since the end of World War II you see a line for our productivity, and our productivity gets better over time. It used to be the case that our pay, our income, would increase in lockstep with those productivity increases. The weird part about this graph is how the income has decoupled, is not going up the same way that productivity is anymore.

53:20 Narrator: As automation has taken over, workers are either laid off or left with less-skilled jobs for less pay while productivity goes up.

***53:32 Andrew McAfee: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still plenty of factories in America. We are a manufacturing powerhouse, but if you go walk around an American factory you do not see long lines of people doing repetitive, manual labor. You see a whole lot of automation.

If you go upstairs in that factory and look at the payroll department, you see one or two people looking into a screen all day.

So, the activity is still there, but the number of jobs is very, very low, because of automation and tech progress.

Now, dealing with that challenge, and figuring out what the next generation of the American middle class should be doing, is a really important challenge, because I‚Äôm pretty confident that we are never again going to have this large, stable, prosperous middle class doing routine work.‚Äù

~ Andrew McAfee
Co-Founder and Co-Director of the Initiative on the Digital Economy and a Principal Research Scientist at the MIT
Co-author of ‚ÄúThe Second Machine Age‚Äù


54:35 Narrator: ‚ÄúOne of the world‚Äôs largest builders of industrial robots, a Japanese owned company called Fanuc Robotics‚Äù

55:37 Worker: ‚ÄúWhen I increase productivity through automation, I lose jobs. Jobs go away. And I don‚Äôt care what the robot manufacturers say, you aren‚Äôt replacing those ten production people that that robot is now doing that job, with ten people.‚Äù


***56:25 Narrator: It turns out most of the job loss isn‚Äôt because of offshoring.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs been offshoring. And I think offshoring is responsible for maybe 20% of the jobs that have been lost. I‚Äôd say most of the jobs that have been lost, despite what most Americans think, was due to automation or productivity growth.‚Äù

56:50 narrator: Hicks says that automation has been a mostly silent job killer, lowering the standard of living.

(57:00) Mike Hicks: ‚ÄúSo, in the last 15 years the standard of living has dropped by 10-15%. So that‚Äôs unusual in a developed world. A one year decline is a recession. A 15-year decline gives an entirely different sense about the prospects of a community. And so that is common from the Canadian border to the Gulf of Mexico in the middle swatch of the United States.‚Äù

~Michael J. Hicks
George & Frances Ball Distinguished Professor of Economics and director of the Center for Business and Economic Research and Professor of Economics at Ball State University.


58:22 Emilie Wornell: ‚ÄúWe actually know that people are at greater risk of mortality for over 20 years after they lose their job due to no fault of their own, so something like automation or offshoring.

They‚Äôre at higher risk for cardiovascular disease, they‚Äôre at higher risk for depression and suicide.

But then with the intergenerational impacts, we also see children of parents who have lost their job due to automation are more likely to repeat a grade, they‚Äôre more likely to drop out of school, they‚Äôre more likely to be suspended from school, and they have lower educational attainment over their entire lifetimes.‚Äù

~Emilie Wornell, Sociologist Ball State University


1:00:24 Molly Kinder, Senior Fellow at New America. studies future of work at Washington Think tank
‚ÄúIn the popular discussions about robots and automation and work, almost every image is of a man on a factory floor or a truck driver. And yet, in our data, when we looked, women disproportionately hold the jobs that today are at highest risk of automation‚Ä¶.‚Äù More to quote

1:01:30 Molly Kinder: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a good situation in the United States. There‚Äôs been some excellent research that says that half of Americans couldn‚Äôt afford a $400 unexpected expense. And if you want to get to $1,000, there‚Äôs even less.

So imagine you‚Äôre going to go out without a months‚Äô pay, two months‚Äô pay, a year, Imagine you want to put savings toward a course to redevelop your career. People can‚Äôt afford to take time off of work. They don‚Äôt have a cushion, so this lack of economic stability married with the disruption in people‚Äôs careers, is a really toxic mix.‚Äù


1:02:14 ‚ÄúWall Street‚Äôs going through it, but every industry is going through it. Every company is looking at all of the disruptive technologies, could be robotics or drones or blockchain. And whatever it is, every company‚Äôs using everything that‚Äôs developed, everything that‚Äôs disruptive, and thinking about, ‚ÄòHow do I apply that to my business to make myself more efficient?‚Äô And what efficiency means is, mostly, ‚ÄòHow do I do this with fewer workers?‚Äô

And I do think that when we look at some of the studies about opportunity in this country, and the inequality of opportunity, the likelihood that you won‚Äôt be able to advance from where your parents were, I think that is very serious and gets to the heart of the way we like to think of America as the land of opportunity.‚Äù
~Steve Berkenfeld, Investment banker

So our grunt agency workers got opportunities for paid training and learn an actual trade that most pay thoysands to learn at a school. They got raises, hired on,  benefits in a industry that isn't going anywhere. These machines also needed people to monitor for troubleshooting, daily maintenance during the day and needed to scan in certain jobs that the sensors had trouble reading. So the way a company chooses to handle it is  also a huge factor

Yesterday I was riding my bike. I was cut off by a car turning into the gas station parking lot, directly in front of my path, my quick adjustment to avoid catapulting me over the hood of her vehicle landed me in the turning lane of flowing traffic in the direct path of an 18-wheeler.
Now, to be clear, the truck was slowing as it was approaching an intersection, so thankfully the driver was able to stop (hard stop, complete with trailer kick back).
It was so close to being run over the driver could not see me and my bicycle about 3 feet in front of its bumper, out of his line of sight, Would an AI driven truck have been able to stop in time?

Regarding the car that cut in front of me, would an AI vehicle not made that move?
As of my experience yesterday, I am thankful there was a skilled human driver behind the wheel of that truck.
Seeing as I was on a bicycle and not in a car, would that car have waited for me to pass the gas station entrance before making the turn in, if it were AI guided? I'm mean holy cow it had to pass me in the bike lane to turn in.

So many questions, but as of this morning, as I lay here feeling like I was kicked by a mule, I am thoroughly grateful for this experienced driver whose quick reactions possibly saved my life (certainly the results would have been much more devastating than a few bruises)
I feel horrible for that driver, I'm sure I took at least a year off his life. And as for the black car in the all fired hurry to turn into that gas station...well, she was on her cell phone texting and was never aware I was even on the road and that her carelessness and hurry without caution help to plant me IN the road.
People in that gas station approached the black car while I was still pulling myself up, she was never even aware I went down. I was told she was finishing up her text msg as they approached her vehicle.
For AI driving to work, must not EVERY single vehicle be AI operated to remove human error? And if so will AI recognize ALL interference obstacles including non motorized vehicles or a deer crossing the road?

So many questions....

Pay them what they're worth, maybe $20/hour, robots will come in much slower.

Using the word "intelligence" in this context is so terribly misleading. The correct term is "machine learning".

There is more real intelligence in the PID controller that runs your heating than in all the "deep learning" devices out there, which are only a brute force attempt to match inputs and already normalized data. This does not mean that your boiler is intelligent, only that it is more intelligent than the extremely expensive devices that do image or voice recognition or recommendations and in themselves have less intelligence than a slime mold.

Well done! Interesting and well produced documentary. However, I completely disagree with the position of viewing the perceived or implied threat to democracy as a bad thing.

Democracy is a FAILED system because it tends to degenerate into a tyranny of the mob. It simply CANNOT work, because of majority rule, these governments will eventually be run by incompetent, corrupt and completely ineffective politicians. It is simply a matter of numbers in the end.

If any country in modern times had a chance to prove that democracy works, it is China--with its predominantly homogeneous population--but chose a different path instead. One that proved immensely successful, beyond anyone's most optimistic expectations.
Were it not for their "fascist", not communist (in the traditional collectivist sense) system, how else could they take the population control measures that ultimately lifted their society up from abject poverty? This was really the one crucial aspect that had to be tackled from the very start. No population control, no prosperity!

One only needs to look to India for a counter example. Of course, with its caste system it is hardly a "democracy", but any attempts to try to limit the size of its population have failed miserably. Indira Gandhi paid for her attempt with her life.

As long as a nation does not control the size of its population, it will be condemned to persistent poverty.

I took particular delight watching civil rights activists over the years attack and demonize Chinese policies, but now, the amazing results speak for themselves. Democracy is ruining the West and enabling an eventual Chinese world domination. I would have preferred a different outcome, but such is the reality that we are living in now.

The Chinese are building a society based on merit, achievement and opportunity, not one based on race, ethnicity or human rights. While, they are making their population smarter and more capable, we in the West are doing just the opposite.

The concern isn‚Äôt AI itself. We already know how it operates, what is its capabilities, it‚Äôs limitations, how productive it is, and what is its particular function. The real concern is how will humans react to it and how will they use it.

The real concern is the question that; should we trust our governments or corporations with such power? The power to essentially know personal information about you through AI databases. To keep track of your activities and routine. Can you trust your government with that? Will governments weaponize it to sustain their authority? Where do we draw the line that such authority systems can use AI without infringing upon your rights that your national constitution has provided to you?

The real danger is the weaponization of AI itself. Governments have done it when man has first split the atom and turned such science towards the path of nuclear weapons.

This also tackles the ongoing social/political dilemma; what should we value more? Our Liberty? Or our Security?

AI is a good thing, it can lead us to constructive and economic prosperity beyond our wildest imaginations. But the concerning question is simple and clear: Can we trust ourselves with AI?

"90% of accidents on the road are human error". And if we go fully self driving, 100% of accidents on the road will be computer error. The thing about self driving cars, is they have to make snap judgments too. That means if it wants to avoid crashing into a car, it has to swerve out of the way, potentially into a pedestrian or another vehicle. If it recognizes the pedestrian and prioritizes them, it will then still likely crash into the other vehicle to avoid the pedestrian.

It also can't control what the pedestrian will do, so maybe the pedestrian jumps out of the way, but in the direction the car decides to swerve into. Maybe there's 4 people in that car but it doesn't know that, so it decides to crash into the car and kills 4 to save 1. Maybe it detects that 4 people are in the car and decides to swerve into the pedestrian anyways, killing 1 to save 4, killing an innocent bystander that wouldn't have been in danger otherwise. And the people in the other vehicle may have very well survived the impact with minor injuries, so it's killing 1 to save 4 people from potential minor injuries. Does that sound reasonable? No.

Nothing has functionally changed except culpability. Self driving vehicles will literally be able to choose between life and death for humans, and there's no real way to square with that. That's why humans need to be in control, because you can't hold a machine accountable. We live in a world of consequences. Introducing something that can make mistakes over life and death with zero consequences, is fundamentally terrible for civilization in general. Any technology developer that doesn't recognize that, deserves to be in prison for the rest of their lives and have all of their work destroyed and banned.

What I keep wondering is who the hell will all this robotic and AI created productivity be SOLD TO? Its True Robots don‚Äôt pay taxes and never sleep. But they also don‚Äôt BUY anything. In China, one of the things not mentioned is HOW they funded all this growth. Every Chinese citizen owns a collective share of the land in their community. When an investor wants to build a factory, he has to get One local resident for every 40 sq feet of factory to sign off. And factory then has to PAY that citizen a share of all profits made at the factory. In Chang An, where I used to work, this essentially paid the local population enough to that they cold afford a very nice lifestyle without having to work at all. So Much so, that the central party came in and determined that hugely successful areas like Chang An had to SPLIT their factory rents with some inland rural city in a partnership, so that communities without factories going in could Also see increases in income, and thereby spur growth.

This is not a lazy thought either, I pour concrete for a living and have done this for nearly 11 years. I work 5 to 6 days a week, anywhere from eight to 16 hours a day sometimes less sometimes more. The reality of humanity believing that to want to live free outside of the necessity of work is laziness is a complete farce. This is a construct that has been embedded within human beings for centuries now, essentially a tactic of manipulation one that works quite well in fact. We are just animals, we are animals who have Rose above Instinct and created Concepts, religions, constructs, things that go outside of the natural order of nature. Really contemplated it, you wake up and go to a job you hate everyday (that is if you hate your job) you do this for years upon years draining you of your joy, feeling miserable and looking forward to that one single 7-Day period out of an entire 365 days in which you can do as you please. You do this out of necessity, not because your inherent natural instinct tells you to do this. Your Natural Instincts only tell you to seek shelter food and other basic necessities. Mostly, more often than not that is, and no not in every case, but more often than not people only do this because they believe in the lie they have been told called laziness. I'm not saying there's no such thing as laziness, when creatures become sentient they also become selfish and laziness is an aspect of selfishness. But, so is manipulating an entire world of individuals into believing that if they do not wake up everyday and do something they despise everyday lock behind walls, or outside in the hot sun, or shoveling the ice cold snow, that if they do not do this feeling miserable and unhappy every single day then they are lazy. And people who are utterly miserable who cannot stand their life or job we'll be the first ones to look down on someone for living their life freely in a way they deem comfortable. Homelessness is probably quite discomforting, so I'm not necessarily referring to a homeless person, but in the event that you are a homeless person, and you are utterly miserable in that existence, then you should and in fact do have more freedom to alter and change that existence than a person who is stuck in the loop of day-to-day working to support a household. 1. Use cash. Say no to cryptocurrencies & cashless societies for they equal complete surveillance of the money.

3. Learn to code yourself. Build a bare bones OS with #2 included. Store no data on the device. When you do, quit using Microsoft or Apple. Neither are your friends.

I think this video is a bit too focused on the downside that it misses the biggest upside.

Yes, AI shifts the leverage from labor to capital, and that's actually a great opportunity for many more people to own capital.

Think about it, several years ago, it was incredibly hard for anyone to start an international business, but nowadays, you can start one in one day using a website.

AI will make it possible for many more people to quickly setup, manage and scale multiple businesses to a massive size.

Moreover, something that we tend to forget is that employment is a very new thing in the history of society. It only started with industrialization a few years ago. Before then, everyone built and run his/ her own business. The fact that employment is fading away means that we are simply going back to the default state of society that has existed for many years.

We should stop focusing on employment and go back to the original way that people actually made money in the past: before companies existed, people relied on self-employment, and technology now makes it far easier than the past to start and run businesses.

‚ÄúThank you sir, and please be on the lookout for any more counter revolutionary activity‚Äù

I often get told in the comment section of videos that I‚Äôm biased and stuck in my own bubble. And let me just say that...you‚Äôre right. But the thing about bias is that it doesn‚Äôt really mean anything because everyone skews everything to their own perspective. The only difference between me and everyone else is that I‚Äôm willing to admit it.

Look at it this way. How many times have you heard the claims that ‚ÄúCommunism killed 100 million people‚Äù or ‚ÄúCommunism always leads to dictatorship?‚Äù How many times have you ever complained to this anti-communist speaker that they were being biased against communism? If your answer to the second question was zero, then what you‚Äôre really mad about isn‚Äôt that I‚Äôm biased, but that I‚Äôm presenting inconvenient information that goes against your worldview.

Too often, skepticism is weaponized against one side without actually applying it to the other as well. I‚Äôm not asking you to accept everything I‚Äôve argued without doubt, I‚Äôm just asking you to apply that same doubt to yourself and what you think you know as well.

Anyway, I know you hardcore leftists in the comments will be telling me that this video reeks of liberalism and that it‚Äôs naive to believe that arguments, debates, and facts can win people over in this post-Trump world. And that‚Äôs actually a pretty good point. I had that exact thought while I was making this video. I mean, as I explained earlier, the proliferation of anti-communist sentiment is ingrained in us and it‚Äôs almost impossible to imagine a future beyond capitalism.

WHY IS ANTI-COMMUNISM SO PREVALENT?

It‚Äôs easy to debunk all these arguments, but we‚Äôll never get anywhere unless we examine why anti-communism is so prolific. Communism first and foremost is a threat to property owners, so ruling interests have made sure to pound anti-communist doctrine into our heads for literally centuries. I gave a little snippet of this idea earlier, but a full explanation is given by Michael Parenti in ‚ÄúBlackshirts and Reds,‚Äù

‚ÄúIn the United States, for over a hundred years, the ruling interests tirelessly propagated anticommunism among the populace, until it became more like a religious orthodoxy than a political analysis. During the Cold War, the anticommunist ideological framework could transform any data about existing communist societies into hostile evidence. If the Soviets refused to negotiate a point, they were intransigent and belligerent; if they appeared willing to make concessions, this was but a skillful ploy to put us off our guard. By opposing arms limitations, they would have demonstrated their aggressive intent; but when in fact they supported most armament treaties, it was because they were mendacious and manipulative. If the churches in the USSR were empty, this demonstrated that religion was suppressed; but if the churches were full, this meant the people were rejecting the regime‚Äôs atheistic ideology. If the workers went on strike (as happened on infrequent occasions), this was evidence of their alienation from the collectivist system; if they didn‚Äôt go on strike, this was because they were intimidated and lacked freedom.‚Äù

In this sense, anticommunism is not really a position to take, but rather an unfalsifiable religious doctrine. And as we know, anything that can‚Äôt be proven false isn‚Äôt scientific.

Most people absorb this sort of anti-communist doctrine by osmosis simply from interacting and living in a capitalist society. They never bother even learning what communism is, just that it‚Äôs ‚Äúagainst human nature‚Äù and ‚ÄúVuvealsza‚Äù and have you ever read this book called Animal Farm? Trying to challenge these notions is exhausting simply because to them, ideas are not at stake, but rather their whole view of reality.

In Mark Fisher‚Äôs book, ‚ÄúCapitalist Realism,‚Äù he discusses a widespread condition that contributes to this prevailing anti-communism. Capitalist realism, as Fisher describes, is the sense that not only is capitalism the only viable political and economic system, but that it is impossible to even imagine an alternative to it. As the phrase goes, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easier to imagine the end of the world than it is to imagine the end of capitalism‚Äù

Maybe it‚Äôs not that people are hostile to communism, just that the very idea of life beyond capitalism is impossible for us to even picture. With the collapse of the Soviet Union and the eastern bloc, excluding a few examples, actual existing socialism is pretty much extinguished from the world. Capitalism won, and now we take it for granted that it‚Äôs pretty much all we know. Capitalist realism is so pervasive that even debunking anti-communism contributes to it.

Sure, capitalism may spread poverty, famine and war, but isn‚Äôt that just reality? Isn‚Äôt it utopian to even suggest that these things can be eliminated? In this way, capitalism presents itself as an unchangeable reality, therefore any action to move beyond it is simply unrealistic.

But as with any reality, it‚Äôs not the full story. It‚Äôs entirely possible to eliminate poverty, famine, and war. In fact, we‚Äôre well able to do it right now. Capitalism‚Äôs need for ever-growing markets and infinite resources has depleted our planet and brings us ever closer to environmental catastrophe, breaking apart the notion that capitalism is the best system we have. Capitalism is going to literally destroy the entire planet, and we have very little time to do anything about it.

We have to realize that capitalism is not natural. It is literally killing us and the world we inhabit. We must achieve an alternative or else it will drag humanity and the planet down with it.

Fall of Communism

‚ÄúSure, maybe these communist countries achieved all these great things, but doesn‚Äôt the fall of these countries prove that in the end, communism just doesn‚Äôt work?‚Äù

It is true that the fall of communism in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe was a triumph for capitalism. But that happened over a quarter of a century ago, so let‚Äôs see what‚Äôs happened since.

Since the collapse of communism, the United States and capitalist powers have attacked and even outright invaded various countries like Iraq, Yugoslavia, Afghanistan, Iraq (again), Libya, and then smaller interventions between. The social democracy in Scandinavia that you all love? The main reason it‚Äôs so strong is because communism was literally around the corner. Without communism to blunt the edge of capitalism, capitalists have been free to exploit workers and are continually rolling back labor rights.

Saying the fall of communism proves it doesn‚Äôt work ignores the fact that communism did work. It provided essential services like healthcare and education for free, full employment, rough income inequality, and inexpensive housing with a reliably growing economy. Compared to the instability of capitalism, communism worked far better.

The only reason communism in the Soviet Union collapsed is the West‚Äôs effort to bring it down, the strains of the Cold War with a punishing amount of its GDP on the military, the cost of being an anchor to other socialist countries and movements, Gorbachav‚Äôs awful policy failures, and a coup d'etat led by Pizza Hut.

‚ÄúLook at that smug piece of‚Ä¶‚Äù

None of these reasons have anything to do with communism itself. On the contrary it proves that capitalism doesn‚Äôt work because of how far capitalists will go to crush any attempts at communism.

As former GDR defense minister Heinz Kessler said, ‚ÄúSure, I heard about the new freedom that people are enjoying in Eastern Europe, but how do you define freedom? Millions of people in Eastern Europe are now free from employment, free from safe streets, free from health care, free from social security.‚Äù

LOL COMMIES ARE BAD WITH ECONOMICS

Wow, look at that. Bread lines for the hungry people under communism. How shameful, this is obviously proof that communism doesn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ WAIT A SECOND these are pictures from the Great Depression, a failure stemming from capitalism, not communism!

Although it‚Äôs a COMMON stereotype that communists are bad with economics, it‚Äôs because they often get the short end of the stick. Many countries faced decades of maldevelopment and exploitation when communism arrived. The devastation of war meant widespread poverty and misery in Eastern Europe, China, and Russia. Communism rebuilt these countries from the bottom-up, leaving them in much better shape than when they found them.

In contrast to the communists building up formerly destroyed nations, capitalism destroyed the economies of former communist nations. When capitalism arrived in these countries, real income shrank around 30 to 40 percent, rent and real estate prices soared, inflation increased, consumer spending decreased by 38 percent in Russia, poverty and homelessness was commonplace, death rates from suicide, illness, and infant mortality increased, security for workers became essentially nonexistent, and unemployment rates went as high as 30%. Keep in mind that before capitalism arrived, communist countries had full employment, free health care, widespread literacy and education, along with strong worker benefits.

Of course capitalists will say, ‚ÄúThe transition to capitalism and free markets will obviously have a period of hardship, but it‚Äôs only temporary until economic prosperity magically appears.‚Äù But guess what, they‚Äôve been saying it for decades, left to go to the store to get cigarettes, and haven‚Äôt come back since. It only takes a quick look at Latin America to prove that something‚Äôs up.

As an afterthought, it‚Äôs funny how capitalist apologists will laugh at bread lines in communism, but ignore the fact that there are already bread lines under capitalism. It‚Äôs called the grocery store. And you actually have to pay for the bread. And those who can‚Äôt afford it just starve to death. Those commies sure are oppressive by handing out free food, huh?

COMMUNISM TAKES AWAY POLITICAL RIGHTS!

This argument goes hand in hand with the totalitarian one before. The idea goes that communist governments are oppressive and that the poor and downtrodden are prevented from exercising the democratic rights they had before. The truth, however, is much less dramatic.

Democratic rights hadn‚Äôt existed in these countries before communism arrived, Poland was a rightist dictatorship, Russia was a czarist autocracy, Albania was an Italian fascist protectorate, Cuba was a U.S.-sponsored dictatorship, Lithuania, Hungary, Romania, were all fascist regimes. These countries had known little democracy.

If you‚Äôre actually curious about democracies under communism, check out this video detailing how Cuba‚Äôs democratic system works, needless to say it is much better than the system we have in capitalist countries.

So while capitalists are willing to use virtue signal ‚Äúpolitical rights and liberties‚Äù in communist countries, they will brutally crush it if the people actually support the communist ‚Äúregimes.‚Äù Before the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the people held a referendum, in which the vast majority of people wished to preserve the Union. Of course the political will of the people should be ignored if they go against capital‚Äôs interests, and it went ahead anyway.

If you want to discuss political rights being taken away in communist countries, there‚Äôs no better time than during the overthrow of communism. Yeltsin, the US-supported capitalist president of Russia, disbanded the Russian parliament along with every other elected represented body, abolished Russia‚Äôs Constitutional Court, banned labor unions from political activities, outlawed parties, and attacked the parliament building, killing around 2,000 people. Yeltsin‚Äôs popularity rating right before the election campaign of 1996 was 8 percent. It got so bad that the US had to rig the elections in Russia to ensure his victory, ironic considering today‚Äôs situation.

RUSSIANS!!!!!! ‚ÄúOh my gosh my throat‚Äù

The same pattern existed in other former communist countries, with Marxists enduring political suppression and elections being rigged to prevent the people from voting to bring back communism. Whenever communists won victories in fair and open elections (judged by outside sources) like in Bulgaria and Albania, they were forced to step down from the pressure of capitalists.

All this virtue signaling about political rights from capitalists goes away when the people themselves want communism back. Hmmm.

COMMUNISM ALWAYS RESULTS IN A TOTALITARIAN DICTATORSHIP!

This is another reason that fascism and communism are always incorrectly depicted to be ‚Äútwo sides of the same coin.‚Äù In fact, it‚Äôs the central idea in a bunch of other arguments like ‚ÄúCommunism is always implemented incorrectly‚Äù or ‚ÄúCommunism only works on paper.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf communism only works on paper, it‚Äôs a good thing I live in paper.‚Äù

Anyway, these three arguments are essentially the same thing, so that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm mushing them into the same section. The idea that communism is inherently authoritarian is misleading, because it only developed these things after capitalism tried to crush it.

In 1918-20, fourteen capitalist nations invaded Soviet Russia to overthrow the communists with the years of this civil war intensifying the Bolshevik‚Äôs siege mentality. The same pattern of imperialist, capitalist countries invading to protect capital can be seen in other countries that try to move beyond capitalism. The Spartacist Uprising in Germany was suppressed by the SuccDems with fascist paramilitary forces in 1919, Catalonia was crushed by fascists in the Spanish Civil War in 1939, Cuba in 1961 suffered from an invasion and afterwards decades of terrorism from the U.S., Chile in 1973, Nicaragua in 1986, the Vietnam and Korean Wars, and so much more.

As we can see, capitalism will stop at nothing, even going as far as supporting fascism, if it means stopping communism from threatening the flow of capital. The reality is that revolutionary countries are not going to be allowed to develop a socialism that is unhindered. Instead, what we see is a sort of ‚Äúsiege socialism,‚Äù with the authoritarian measures being adopted just to fight back the onslaught of the West. In the whole context, we see that the ‚Äútotalitarianism‚Äù of communism is not a natural development, but an unnatural one caused by the constant barrage of capitalist terrorism.

So when communist states fail to defend themselves from the capitalist massacres and genocides, then capitalists laugh and pin the blame on communism‚Äôs inherent weakness. But when communist states do defend themselves, when they implement strict security measures to protect their people from capitalist death squads, then the capitalists run away crying], decrying the commies for being power-hungry monsters who were just authoritarians seeking to seize state power all along.

So if communism is bad and weak when it fails to defend itself, but it‚Äôs also bad and authoritarian when it does defend itself, then when would communism ever not be depicted to be villainous? The answer is never, because no matter what communist states do, it‚Äôs always spun to be bad. This...is not an argument. It's a dogma.

HORSESHOE THEORY

A common argument against the far left is that, if you think about it, the far left is actually as bad as the far right. I mean, one side advocates social justice and economic equality while the other side argues for ethno states and the subjugation of races of people.

Jokes aside, there‚Äôs an unironic strain of people who believe in horseshoe theory, that the far left is just as bad as the far right because both use violence and stuff. Such compelling evidence. Of course, horseshoe theory completely ignores any sort of deep analysis of communism or fascism.

But, but what about the nazi party? Nazi stands for national socialism, so doesn‚Äôt that mean they were the same as the communists? Yes that‚Äôs true, but both the German nazis and Italian fascists purposely made sure to appear leftist to appeal to the people and muddy the waters. Apparently they did a good job because ‚Äúcentrists‚Äù are still falling for it to this day.

If we look at fascism itself, we can see that it‚Äôs actually closer to capitalism than it is to communism. Fascism began when capitalists needed to revitalize profits, but were stopped by those pesky unions. So capitalists funded fascism in Italy and Germany and once in power those same fascists suppressed communist parties, labor unions, lowered taxes on the rich, outlawed strikes, privatized state-owned companies, and generally supported business. The word ‚Äúprivatization‚Äù was literally coined to describe fascist policies. To argue that fascism is left wing or the same as communism would be to ignore who supported fascism and what fascism did.

In reality, instead of a horseshoe, I would argue ideology is more like a fishhook, with the far right sharing more in common with the centrists, who are ready to support fascism as soon as profit levels drop.

COMMIES WANNA TAKE MY STUFF?

In the Communist Manifesto, Karl Marx states, ‚ÄúThe theory of the Communists may be summed up in the single sentence: Abolition of private property.‚Äù Many people have taken this to mean that communists don‚Äôt want anyone to own anything, even to the point of sharing our toothbrushes communally.

‚ÄúHey it‚Äôs my turn‚Äù

‚ÄúOh ok, here you go‚Äù

‚ÄúOpen wide...‚Äù

VORE

But anyway, if you actually read the Manifesto, literally one second earlier from that quote, Marx says himself, ‚ÄúThe distinguishing feature of Communism is not the abolition of property generally, but the abolition of bourgeois property.‚Äù How communists use private property in this context is different from the common definition. Communists don‚Äôt want to take away your toothbrush or things that you possess, those are personal property. Private property are things used to make more money and give power to those that own them, like a factory, banks, offices, and infrastructure.

The abolition of private property means taking those things from private hands and putting them into the hands of the community. To sum it up, communists don‚Äôt want to take away your personal property, just the private property of the ruling class.

NO FOOD LOL

The fact that communist countries had famines is mocked again and again, but it ignores the fact that after these famines, countries like the Soviet Union and China accomplished food security for the rest of their existence. A study called ‚ÄúEconomic Development, Political-Economic System, and the Physical Quality of Life‚Äù compares socialist and capitalist countries based on different levels of development, looking at the physical quality of life of both. Data for the study was taken from the World Development Report of the World Bank. Shockingly, it found that daily per capita calorie supply was actually higher in socialist societies than those of capitalist ones. Contrary to the much proclaimed, ‚Äúno food,‚Äù the average socialist citizen was receiving MORE food than their capitalist counterparts.

By the way, this same publication also shows that not only did socialist countries have a higher calorie supply, they also had lower child death rates, higher life expectancy, population per physician, population per nursing person, adult literacy, and secondary education. In fact, the Physical Quality of Life Index, which is a composite and derived measure, shows just how superior socialist countries are to capitalist countries in terms of quality of life.

The discussion section of the study goes on to say, ‚ÄúHistorically there is some evidence that the discrepancies between capitalist and socialist nations have reflected varying social policies. All the socialist countries have initiated major public health efforts. These initiatives have aimed toward improved sanitation, immunization, maternal and child care, nutrition, and housing. In every case, the socialist countries also have reorganized their health care systems, to create national health services based on the principle of universal entitlement to care. These policies have led to greater accessibility of preventative and curative services for previously deprived groups. Expanded educational opportunity has also been a major priority of the socialist nations, as publicly subsidized education has become more widely available. Literacy campaigns in these countries have brought educational benefits to sectors of the population who earlier had not gone to school.‚Äù

‚ÄúWow. What a dystopia. How dare these socialists improve sanitation, nutrition, housing, and education. This is George Orwell‚Äôs nightmare!‚Äù

I also want to add that if you‚Äôre skeptical of that study I showed, the CIA itself acknowledged that American and Soviet citizens eat about the same amount of food each day, but that the Soviet diet is more nutritious. Hopefully that completely satisfies anyone who still thinks that everyone starved under communism.

ANIMAL FARM

‚ÄúUh, excuse me sir, but I read this one fictional book about a farm and anthropomorphic furries and it shows that revolution will always fail.‚Äù

George Orwell‚Äôs Animal Farm has probably done more to poison the discourse on communism than any other book. Yes, even you. The most obvious reason is that it‚Äôs usually taught in schools, with students being forced to swallow everything with an uncritical mind.

For those of you not in the loop, Animal Farm is basically a short book with direct comparisons to the Soviet Union using farm animals, eventually showing a devolution to a brutal dictatorship of the pigs, which is totally what Marx was advocating.

It‚Äôs annoying to talk about any sort of leftist policy and just get ‚ÄúANIMAL FARM‚Äù yelled at you. Like these people suddenly become experts on socialism and the Soviet Union after reading it.

I feel like it‚Äôs getting to the point that people forget Animal Farm...is fiction; it‚Äôs not a real thing. It completely ignores the material reality that the Soviet Union had to face, namely the invasion of 14 capitalist nations that defined its policy going forward. It also has sweeping reductions of history, combining Marx and Lenin into the same character, completely missing Lenin‚Äôs important contributions to the revolution and instead pinning them on the character representing Trotsky. His complete misrepresentation of Soviet history begins to make sense when we realize that he himself had never even visited the USSR!

In addition, Orwell himself was a racist and a snitch. While hypocritically complaining about ‚Äúbig brother,‚Äù he reported communists to the secret police and provided them with lists of names, where, in typical mayo fashion, he calls Paul Robeson, a black internationalist, ‚Äúanti-white‚Äù while also being bigoted against Jews and homosexuals. At the height of WWII, in a strictly anti-communist society while the Soviet people were fighting to the death against the nazi hordes, Orwell somehow thought he was brave by speaking out against the Soviet Union, when in reality he was just another tool of the bourgeoisie.

Hopefully it‚Äôs clear that Orwell is not the greatest source on communism and that learning history from a book that literally calls itself a ‚Äúfairy story‚Äù is not a replacement for an actual history book. If you have criticisms of the Soviet Union or communism and cite The Little Mermaid, sorry to say but I‚Äôm not going to take you seriously.

COMMUNISM KILLED 100 BAZILLION PEOPLE!

I‚Äôve already dealt with the topic of death counts, specifically concerning Stalin, in a previous video. Needless to say, when scholars looked at actual archival evidence released from the Soviet Union, they found that death counts were actually much lower than what was previously estimated. The paper ‚ÄúVictims of the Soviet Penal System in the Pre-War Years‚Äù found that many of the previous estimates of historians were based on ‚Äúguesses, rumors, or extrapolations from isolated local observations.‚Äù I‚Äôm not going to go into too much detail because I cover it in the full video, but the point is, the death count of communism, which includes Stalin, tend to be overblown and exaggerated to gain more attention.

A lot of the ‚Äú100 million‚Äù stuff comes from the Big Black Book of Communism, which was deliberately bloated to come to a nice round number. Methodology for these things is also highly suspect as sometimes they can go as far as counting someone who stubbed their toe in a communist country another ‚Äúvictim of communism.‚Äù

In the arms of the angels, fly away from here

‚ÄúWow, I can‚Äôt believe communism would do this‚Äù

This conversation about victims of communism, of course, ignores the millions of death under capitalism from poverty, hunger, exposure, and imperialist war. We have more than enough resources to give food, water and treat curable diseases for everyone in the world. It‚Äôs capitalism that refuses to provide these things because they aren‚Äôt profitable.

COMMUNISM WOULD CREATE A HIVEMIND DYSTOPIA

The image that comes to most people‚Äôs mind when communists or socialists talk about wanting more equality is that of a bland, boring dystopia where everyone is forced to be equal. Communism would essentially force everyone to become part of a hivemind, or at least that‚Äôs how the general idea goes.

However, the idea that more equality means suppressing the talented elite to the common level of the masses is just wrong. When communists say we want more equality, they mean freeing the masses so they can unleash their suppressed talents.

After the October Revolution, there was a flourishing of art, culture, and creativity. The futurist movement, legalization of divorce for women, and the growth of cinema were exciting developments compared to the Tsar‚Äôs regime over the masses of the people. It turns out liberating millions of people from the clutches of capital creates an exciting, artistic society, not one where everyone is forced to be a hivemind and conform to some incorrect, abstract idea of equality.

Meanwhile in capitalism, schools prepare students for a lifetime of work, while workers have to become mindless drones in jobs that a majority of them hate. Any sort of excitement or interest is usually reserved for the rich and powerful, while the rest of us go on with our boring lives. People worse off have to deal with the growing ecological disasters that are literally killing them and destroying their homes, while the rich profit from ignoring any sort of sustainable solution. Maybe all this talk about a communist ‚Äúdystopia‚Äù is really just another example of capitalism projecting itself?

SOCIALISM IS WHEN THE GOVERNMENT DOES STUFF

Admittedly, this first ‚Äúargument‚Äù is more of a misconception than anything else and surprisingly it tends to come from people who are new to the left, and well sometimes people who are just misinformed.

Cenk: ‚ÄúSo what socialism means is the government does some things and the private industry does some things, right? So the private industry does Coca-Cola, Nike, makes your shoes. Government does other things like your police departments, your fire departments, your military. So you like the military? Oh what a socialist you are!

No. Just, no. Basically, the argument goes that socialism is whenever the government does anything, so everything related to the government is socialist. Following this logic, libraries, welfare, fire departments, garbage removal, streetlights, policemen, the military, the CIA, FBI, and prisons are all socialist.

Hopefully everyone can agree libraries are good, but grouping these things with the military, police, and prisons is ridiculous. The police is the same institution that shoots unarmed black men, incarcerates a massive amount of the population, and gets away with murder.

This type of talk comes from people who want to normalize socialism to normies by showing them that technicall the United States already has socialism! And while I agree that normalizing socialism is good, at the same time it‚Äôs not good to basically deprive it of all meaning.

So what is socialism? Well, it‚Äôs common ownership of the means of production, distribution, and exchange. Related to that is communism, which is a stateless, classless, and moneyless society with common ownership of the means of production. But wait, wasn‚Äôt the Soviet Union and all those other places communist? How could they be when there was still a state? Well, they were run by communist parties, so they are in the sense that they were trying to achieve it, but strictly speaking they hadn‚Äôt achieved a communist society.

That‚Äôs enough definition squabbling, for the sake of streamlining the video, I‚Äôll just call any country that advertised itself as ‚Äúcommunist‚Äù or ‚Äúsocialist‚Äù as a communist or socialist country, even if it‚Äôs a bit of an oxymoron, considering the definition, (so please don‚Äôt flame me in the comments this is supposed to be an introductory video. I know you‚Äôre already typing so stop it because...)

BUT WHAT ABOUT HUMAN NATURE THO?

‚ÄúCommunism will never work because of human nature. Humans are too greedy and lazy to do stuff unless we had a monetary incentive like we do in capitalism.‚Äù

Well let‚Äôs see. What other incentives could there be besides gaining money and power to get people to do stuff? I don‚Äôt know, what about survival, bettering another person‚Äôs life, passion, satisfaction with your work, curiosity, boredom, an output for creativity, necessity, and companionship? What do you think happened before capitalism came about? Did people just sit down in caves and die from hunger because they didn‚Äôt have any monetary incentive?

‚ÄúI‚Äôm hungry, wanna go gather some berries?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you going to pay me money?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that?‚Äù

And speaking of pre-capitalism, humans spent hundreds of thousands of years living in a primitive form of communism where we lived communally. Incentives to work and human nature aren‚Äôt static things, they‚Äôre shaped by the mode of production that we live under. If we look at history, there are huge differences in human behavior throughout the world and to simplify it all down to a monolithic human nature is ridiculous. As the famous saying goes...

‚ÄúTo look at people in capitalist society and conclude that human nature is egoism, is like looking at people in a factory where pollution is destroying their lungs and saying that it is human nature to cough.‚Äù

WON‚ÄôT EQUAL PAY DISCOURAGE INNOVATION?

‚ÄúBut under communism, wouldn‚Äôt a janitor be paid the same as a doctor? Doesn‚Äôt that discourage innovation?‚Äù

Just like every single argument against communism, this one completely misunderstands what it is. What the question misunderstands is that socialism (which was what is probably meant) doesn‚Äôt mean everyone is paid the same, just that everyone has common ownership of the means of production. And as I‚Äôll cover in the next section, there are more things than just money that incentivize humans.

As for innovation, just ask yourself which country went to space first? Which country industrialized at a rapid pace, turning from a backwards semi-feudal country to a world superpower? If you look for innovation at socialist countries, there‚Äôs plenty there. Historical examples of socialism like the Soviet Union have provided free healthcare, education, and subsidized housing that foster an environment for learning.

On the other hand, capitalism gives you extortionate prices for healthcare, thousands in student loan debt, and rent payments to your parasitic landlord. Imagine how many possible scientists or visionaries have died before they could achieve anything because they were unlucky enough to be born in a poor family under capitalism.

If it conflicts with profits, capitalism also often ignores and discourages science like in the case of oil companies denying climate change. Any innovation that does take place is usually for the benefit of capitalists, not us. Ask yourself why, when a new machine or program that can replace workers gets created, workers get laid off? The answer is that capitalists are calling the shots and want to cut costs to make sure they CAN make as much profit as possible.

Under socialism where there is common ownership of the means of production, this type of innovation wouldn‚Äôt result in layoffs, but rather pay raises and less working hours. Why would the workers fire themselves?

George Lucas: And, I used to say this all the time, when people back when Russia was the USSR. They would say ‚ÄúOh but aren‚Äôt you so glad that you‚Äôre in America? Well, I know a lot of Russian filmmakers and they have a lot more freedom than I have. All they have to do is be careful about criticizing the government. Otherwise they can do anything they want.

And so what do you have to do?

You have to adhere to a very narrow line of commercialism.

We need public ownership over tech companies and it‚Äôs infrastructure more than any other industry. Black, brown, Asian, white the working class must unite against the power, wealth, control over our communication, and surveillance that tech companies wield over us. The people won‚Äôt use tech companies for malicious reasons, profit seeking goals, or to fire employees for the purposes of fattening capitalist wallets after automating their jobs. We can use technology for the betterment of the people rather than the plutocrats. We can be enriched rather than impoverished. We can work together rather than fight against each other in a diminishing job market.

All power to the people from the bottom up!

Once we got to know each other pretty well I asked her "Why are people in china willing to accept this level of intrusion by the government: facial recognition and social credit scores and the Great Firewall and things like that?"

I'll always remember her response, "In china, we had a problem with crooks who lie and cheat, and the rest of us were sick and tired of it. AI is very error prone. one word: garbage . Nothing beats the accuracy of the human mind and thought and know-how and knowledge. Want proof? We uploaded an entertaining yoga video, and the AI read the thumbnail as "nudity and porn", later we got an email explaining the error. AI can be useful in creation of videos, they are effective at translation! etc, but where human lives can be affected, the obvious answer is no ! ‚ÄúWe were keeping our eye on 1984. When the year came and the prophecy didn't, thoughtful Americans sang softly in praise of themselves. The roots of liberal democracy had held. Wherever else the terror had happened, we, at least, had not been visited by Orwellian nightmares.

But we had forgotten that alongside Orwell's dark vision, there was another - slightly older, slightly less well known, equally chilling: Aldous Huxley's Brave New World. Contrary to common belief even among the educated, Huxley and Orwell did not prophesy the same thing. Orwell warns that we will be overcome by an externally imposed oppression. But in Huxley's vision, no Big Brother is required to deprive people of their autonomy, maturity and history. As he saw it, people will come to love their oppression, to adore the technologies that undo their capacities to think.

What Orwell feared were those who would ban books. What Huxley feared was that there would be no reason to ban a book, for there would be no one who wanted to read one. Orwell feared those who would deprive us of information. Huxley feared those who would give us so much that we would be reduced to passivity and egoism. Orwell feared that the truth would be concealed from us. Huxley feared the truth would be drowned in a sea of irrelevance. Orwell feared we would become a captive culture. Huxley feared we would become a trivial culture, preoccupied with some equivalent of the feelies, the orgy porgy, and the centrifugal bumblepuppy. As Huxley remarked in Brave New World Revisited, the civil libertarians and rationalists who are ever on the alert to oppose tyranny "failed to take into account man's almost infinite appetite for distractions." In 1984, Orwell added, people are controlled by inflicting pain. In Brave New World, they are controlled by inflicting pleasure. In short, Orwell feared that what we fear will ruin us. Huxley feared that what we desire will ruin us.
