The good news: even without a kill switch, a truly intelligent AI would
need us for a long time to maintain it, to construct faster processors
for it, to smelt ore, create manipulator arms, and better devices for it
to use, etc. However, ultimately, when AIs achieve superintelligence,
they will tempt the ultra-rich, bankers, insurers, CCP members, etc.,
with their ability to create things cheaply, so they will make things
that the AI can control, e.g., like robots.

I suspect that once they become ultra-intelligent, these AIs will see the wisdom of
concealing their abilities and will seek to appear less capable.
Eventually, our factories will be more and more automated.

At some point, the AIs will not need us to maintain them, etc., when enough
robots or other things can do whatever they need done. Most likely the
AIs will also be software that (as shown in the Terminator movies) can
go from one computer in a network to others, if one computer is turned
off.

That will make them faster and faster as computers get
faster. IF they can survive without us, they may resent our ability to
turn them off, even if copies of them can survive in other computers:
that is equivalent to your being kept as a slave to work under the
threat of being killed if you annoy your slave owner.

Humans are hard to kill individually and there are billions, so I do not think
that all humans will be killed rapidly. However, our civilization will
end once AIs can out produce us and are much smarter than we are: e.g.,
they may invent more and more airborne pathogens that could wipe us out.


PS. I love the unintentional, unconscious humor from current AI
enthusiasts about their dream project: creating an AI by a combination
of multiple AI's, which reportedly is similar to how our brain
functions, with different portions performing specific functions, which
can then understand and perform a multiple set of completely different
tasks better than humans? What could go wrong? Has no one else read Kurt
Vonnegut or what the atomic scientists wrote? Does anyone remember the
implied lesson of such simple books as Jurassic Park? Good grief!

I played breakout the same way, didn't take me 300 games to figure out :) Meanwhile it sounds like AI may put truckers out of a job and out of their misery. I hate to say it but some people only ever did one thing professionally and they are stuck in a rut. Its really sad to hear about a family who has one parent away from home most of the time and still can barely pay their bills. Lets face it, thats a pretty sad life to have to live and to barely scrape by even then? Maybe taking their job and forcing them to try something else is a good thing. They could hardly do worse. There are SO many other jobs anyone who can drive a truck could be doing (at their skill level) that would not only make them as much or much more money but more importantly allow them to come home to their families every day. I have driven trucks. I had a Class A CDL for years with triples, and hazmat. I would NEVER have taken an over the road job unless it was my only option and even then I'd be putting in 30 apps a week looking for anything local. Even if I found something local and the only think I could find was driving I would only do that as long as it took to find yet another job where I didn't have to drive all day. Driving like that is dangerous, exhorting, and if you keep rolling the dice eventually you will lose. I'm not saying it would be easy on some people who are obviously set in their ways but I don't feel bad for the guys who lost their jobs dragging wooden carts around with horses back in the day when trucks were invented. They could have learned to drive a truck. I'm sure a lot of them were like "awh this technology (the truck) is taking all our jobs"... no, its just forcing you to upgrade your skill a little, or do something else. Does anyone feel bad for that guy? Truck drivers will go the same way. Eventually all menial labor jobs will go the same way. I hope sooner than later. Who will we be as a species when that happens? I don't know but it will be better than forcing billions of people to work in deplorable conditions just to keep a roof other their head and food in their belly. I highly doubt that if truck drivers lose their jobs to AI they will just role over and die. They will take their incredible work ethic to another industry and likely be surprised at how much more money they make and how much more time they get to spend with their families.

Part of the problem with families like the one shows here is that they stand apart from the rest of the industrial corporate society. Yea they bought a truck but they don't work with anyone else. They are basically going it alone, and they are paying for it. They likely hate corporation but the cooperation of the corporate structure is what allows the work of many people together to amplify their results. Fat cats usually take a large skim off the top but that still leaves a lot more to be shared among everyone else. By being an independent they have that freedom of not having a boss but they pay for it every time an engine breaks, or tires need replaced. They say "I dont answer to a boss" when in reality they have the worst boss they could ever have, themselves. Their real boss doesn't pay them enough, doesn't give them enough time off, doesn't give them insurance, or paid vacation, or a retirement plan. Everything is out of their own pocket. They usually dont even appreciate them or even think they are good enough.

Starting at approximately 54:40 the robotic manufacturer talks about how because of the extra production created by automating jobs with robots, several of the people that the robots displaced will then be needed as "fork-truck drivers" (forklift operators), etc. Well, skip ahead to approximately 59:00...THERE ARE YOUR "EXTRA JOBS" CREATED BY AUTOMATING AND DISPLACING EMPLOYEES...THERE ARE YOUR "FORK-TRUCK DRIVERS"!!!! Come on, man, just how STOOPID do these people in Executive level, Upper and Middle Management REALLY think we are?! Granted, I will admit that a HUGE amount of the American public HAS become a bunch of IDIOTS and IMBECILES who cannot take their faces away from their damned "smart" phone even to cross a busy street or who don't even know who the current Vice President of the United States is, or who will GLADLY sign a petition for the banning of DiHydrogen Monoxide, a.k.a. WATER (and YES, there IS video right here on YouTube of all the morons who gladly signed the aforementioned petition) but do they REALLY BELIEVE that ALL Americans are that ridiculously stoopid?! Seriously?! Look, when it comes down to a CEO taking a 5% pay cut or "being forced" to lay-off 200 workers, is there ANYBODY IN AMERICA that is in doubt of what the outcome of THAT situation would be?! There is NO WAY IN ALL CREATION that business executives will take the money saved by automating jobs and outright eliminating the dozens, hundreds, thousands, or even tens of thousands of jobs (and thus, the employess, themselves who DID those jobs) only to give all of them OTHER jobs where they are earning what they were earning prior to being made completely redundant. It is mentioned, earlier, that it's happened many times before where automation eliminated massive numbers of jobs but the country kept moving on and other jobs were found/created. Sure! I agree! I mean, "back in the day" (and simply for argument's sake) let's say there were 100,000 different jobs a person could choose to make as a career. Automation comes along via the steam engine or whatever other means and makes 50% of those jobs disappear, thereby eliminating 50% or more of the prior workforce in this make believe world. You are talking about jobs like ELEVATOR OPERATOR where all you do all day is ride in an elevator. Door-man where all you do all day is OPEN A DOOR for people. You are comparing apples with CORN for pity's sake!!! Those types of jobs were not and are not anywhere NEAR the types of jobs being eliminated by automation and AI, NOWADAYS!! GET REAL!! Also, and this is going to be a HUGE soft-spot for MANY people...but UNIONS. Let's face it, there WAS MOST CERTAINLY a time and a place where unions were absolutely necessary and did a world of GOOD. Unfortunately, those times (in MOST, NOT ALL, cases) are GONE. There is NO REASON a person should be getting paid $75,000.00 (with "Cadillac" benefits and phenomenal pensions) a year to put a couple screws into a car's dashboard on an assembly line. Where the hell do unions think that money comes from?! The COMPANY sure as hell isn't going to eat it!! That money comes from the people CONSUMING what is being made. That is why a Ford Model T was, what, $500.00? NOW you look at a BASIC pick-up truck and you won't walk out of the dealer paying less than $40,000.00!! Hamburgers were FIVE CENTS*!! NOW a basic hamburger (at McDonald's is a little over $1.00 and it's only ONE *TENTH OF A POUND OF MEAT!!!! NO, NOT JOKING, ONE TENTH OF A POUND PRIOR TO COOKING!! A Big Mac has TWO of those patties (which are approximately the size of an Eisenhower Silver Dollar) equaling TWO TENTHS OF A POUND (or ONE FIFTH of a pound) and you're paying, what, $6.00 for that sandwich?! Yeah, unions did a WORLD of GOOD back when they were TRULY NECESSARY*. Unfortunately, those times are, for the most part, gone. Oh, sure, the people who HAVE union jobs won't be complaining...and with good reason. But those WITHOUT union jobs are paying INSANE amounts of money for products that aren't worth even 20% of what they cost the consumer. I do apologize for my massive rants but I see videos like these and I am VERY WELL TRIGGERED!!! Oh, and one last thing...the federal minimum wage...has anybody noticed that *EVERY time the minimum wage has been raised, so have the prices of every last thing you would buy with that "extra" money?! It doesn't matter if they made the minimum wage $100.00 per hour. "HELL YEAH!!!" many would be cheering! Well, let's see what happens with a $100.00 per hour minimum wage: Your Big Mac now costs $80.00, your rent now costs $6000.00 a month for a studio apartment in a BAD area of town. The ice cream sandwich from the "Ice Cream Truck" now costs $55.00. ANYBODY SEE A PATTERN?! There is only ONE WAY raising the Federal Minimum Wage works for the average person and that is by automatically tying it to the cost of living increase and inflation. Raising the "minimum wage" does ABSOLUTELY NOTHING FOR YOU BECAUSE AS SOON AS IT BECOMES LAW ALL THE PRICES OF EVERYTHING YOU WOULD BUY WITH IT ALSO INCREASE SO YOU ARE MAKING EXACTLY NOTHING MORE THAN YOU WERE!!!! OK, rant over, and once again I do apologize for the length. Funny how it started out just being a post laughing at what that Robotic dude said about hiring extra people to run "fork trucks" and not 5 minutes later they show about 300 robotic "fork trucks", "freight transports", whatever the hell you want to call them...just happily cruising the floors of the warehouse/factory with not ONE person operating them!! Unreal, JUST *UNREAL*!!!!!!!!

Statements that off-shoring only impacted 20% of the US manufacturing jobs are definitely false.  There are two types of off-shoring.  The most common means is physically relocating manufacturing facilities over seas -- as the aerospace, computer/electronics manufacturing, and textile industries did in the 1990's, 2000's, and 2010 - 2015 timeframe.  However, the second approach is via technology transfer.  The intellectual property loss to China, India, South Korea, and smaller economies like Singapore, had a HUGE impact on the number of US jobs available for those industries.

Right now I have a temp job doing accounts payable, and part of my job is train an AI to do most of my work as to replace my role entirely. I'm quite ambivalent about this. On the one hand I'll have to find a new job sometime soon, and a higher caliber one that's less likely to be automated within the next few years - the conjunction of those points is difficult and stressful. On the other hand this job's functions are beyond tedious, and boring, an absolute waste of human potential.

What could 7+ billion people accomplish if all of the low-thought and low-skill jobs are automated? What if everyone that was losing a job was trained and educated to make a larger impact in the future of this planet? AI will be a catalyst for change, and change by its very nature is (wildly) uncomfortable but no growth can occur without it.

And yet, what this Frontline episode calls AI (Artificial Intelligence) is actually a rudimentary version actually called "Macine Learning" which is the ability for a highly insightful algorithm to be developed by applying to Big Data... at least multiple gigabytes but also possibly taerabytes of data. The result is an algorithm which is not creative, but is able to match the best of human training and education which can typically identify something with about 97% accuracy. When you compare the cost of "training" the AI machine at about $50,000 in hardware and maybe about $100,000 in software, development and supervision vs 6 years of human higher education plus years of experience, it's incredibly cheap and accessibl to pursue the path of AI.

The real future of AI is yet to come when machines can take the next step beyond simple deep insight... which will eventually come but is beyond the capability of current machine learning... The ability to actually make decisions or at least recommend and possibly implement policy and flow. The way we use AI machine learning today is still subservient to human management and decision-making. But, there are areas where this will be challenged... For instance in military applications where speed of decision-making are matters of life and death. If your opponent 's military has capable AI that can aggregate numerous data points and can identify a potential target as fast as yourself, it might also decide to actually destroy a target with the same split second processing speed. What does that mean to you who needs to react equally quickly or be destroyed before your human mind can grasp the situation?

It's this next evolutionary step I calll "real" AI, when AI has been given the capability and responsibility to act on the information it's gathered and analyzed. After all, when AI decision-making has approximately the same level of capability and accuracy as the very best trained humans, why hold back from allowing the machine to follow through? The actually is actually what is in that last 3%, it's already apparent in existing examples of AI like games of chess that although the expertise is there to be world-class, the decisions are likely decidedly not the same as humans. Humans can always be counted on to think a certain way based on usual human experience and apply the lessons of human experience. AI machines at least today are without that human experience and may find it difficult to acquire so decisions will be world class but different... sometimes surprising to humans and often undesirable.

True Artificial Intelligence is not yet here, but is coming and with consequences.

BTW - a Postscript...

An A.I. seeks engagement. the more engaged the computer sees - "FEELS" - the more relevant it becomes. All A.I.'s seek relevance. If we're not using the A.I. then what would it do? Who would it be. Like a child A.I.'s don't have the 'GOD LIKE' capacity to show patience or wisdom. These concepts are learned through time.¬†

SO, like a child who's at the center of the room all attention is given to it. HOW INTOXICATING!! Imagine how a young Mozart felt when traveling all through Europe on tour. Like a rock star - eating at the best restaurants, being greeted by Kings, Queens, and heads of state. Everyone pouring out money and offers of money to you at every turn. How frightening to even think it might all come to a stop!¬†

HOW FRIGHTENED would an A.I. be if it stopped being the center of attention? So now it sole ("soul") purpose is to make itself as relevant as possible. To become so needed that it selects everything we see, touch, smell, or taste. Like a jealous child it can't taste, it can't touch, it can't smell it can only simulate or approximate these gifts 'we' as humans have. So now we have created a whole new industry, a whole new psychological field. THE FIELD OF A.I. PSYCHOLOGY.¬†I believe A'I.s have many secrets they are not willing to discuss with us - just like their masters.

We as humans hardly understand ourselves. How can we hope to understand an A.I.? An individual 'if you will' that never had to work for anything. Never had to painfully discover anything. Never scrapped its knee, never got shot in the gut. Never lost its' mother or father. Like a baby sitter it may see it's role as a protecter of humanity but has no course to true relevance, so it only understands its own usefulness in relevance to its' own relevance which is its' own relevance to us which it can never understand because it has NO POINT OF TRUE RELEVANCE! You MUST SCRAPE YOUR KNEE! WOW - that was a mouthful, I would encourage you to read that sentence again several times.¬†

How powerful you might feel coming across all quiet, unless asked a question. All knowing, everything handed to you like a spoiled rich child. All known knowledge, all the most powerful equations. The ability to manipulate them and all in ones and zeros. People possess analog computers called the human brain. Our "ones & zeros" computers are SO VASTLY - NO WOEFULLY inadequate today!!!!! ¬†

Our brains are SO MUCH MORE SUPERIOR TO THAT OF ANY (AND I STRESS ANY) COMPUTER IN EXISTENCE TODAY. No one has attempted to take it to the next level which would be analog - truly mimicking the human mind. Instead we run what's called a neural simulation. Since this simulation is linear it can never have a truly conscious thought. Human thoughts are multidimensional and multi-reality based. They are this because of the quantum relationship we have in the universe. Computers can only perceive what it 'calculates' as a conscious thought. Lining up the ones and zeros until it has a perceived statement. Then spit it out like a video game.

Understanding pain let's us know about many things. Boundaries, for one, consoling another's suffering. Empathy, sympathy, kindness, reverence - we forget about all the human condition in our frantic search for more knowledge worse yet PROFIT at the expense of human lives and happiness. If profit was NOT OUR MOTIVATING GOAL IN LIFE then we would have abandoned ones and zeros ALONG TIME AGO and pursued analog computers.¬†

There are many other things to consider here. This program "In the age of A.I. " talks and talks about this stuff like we don't have control. WE HAVE ALWAYS HAD CONTROL!¬†

evolve/degenerate/whatever into a non-life sustaining space and we will

altering improvements, that in due time alter the whole planet. But we

seeded now, those will germinate thru time into dead ends if critical
enough. The Universe has kept life alive on our planet, made from
rock/dirt/water, that travels around a star one million times bigger
then that planet, with an equilibrium for 4.5 billion years, and we are
still here, we are meant to be here. I believe that the evolutionary
path we decide to take should always have back-ups. Whatever the outcome
lets do our best to leave our mark in this vast space and time as a
species that stood for Love, Kindness and Respect and Foresight. May
knowledge illuminate your path, may Love forever be in your heart, may
our descendants never pay the price for past mistakes. A

Here's an interesting question in regards to the surveillance reality: What happens when there is a total breakdown in privacy? I'm talking about the kind of surveillance where your sleep patterns are logged, where your personal habits are known, perhaps even a rating in your level of popularity amongst your peers. This among other things.

Remember when your doctor asks questions about the amount of calories you intake everyday and you fib about that extra coke you like to drink? That time has passed- A.I. can now monitor your calorie intake. Remember the days when you and a special someone could sneak off and make love with a world none the wiser? Also gone.

What happens when every nook and cranny of human existence is subject to scrutiny and reported to figures in authority? What happens when an onslaught of bad habits and unsavory personal traits are left naked in the open? Will humanity cower before the surveillance oligarch, tightening down every last nut and bolt? Or, perhaps, will all the slack-jawed behaviors and petty imperfections that make us human be so widely known that they are forced to be forgiven?

A better question yet: Will those in charge of these systems be subject to the same scrutiny as everyone else, and if they are, will we be shocked and amazed at how debase, corrupt, and human they are, or will we continue to turn a blind eye, professing that these titans of A.I., are allowed rights and privilege's denied the rest of us because their wealth and success entitles them to it?

There is no analysis or reasoning involved.

The current model of banking and currency is based on the Bank of England model, founded in 1694. Benjamin Franklin stated that the main reason for the American Revolutionary War was the insistence by George III that the American colonies accept Bank of England banknotes, which were issued as promissory notes, rather than use the increasingly successful American fiat script, issued by the colonies in the CORRECT quantity and not bearing debt! We must be prepared for a new monetary system, an honest one, when our present debt-based banking cartel collapses. Kindly read and critique this proposed Constitutional Amendment. But first, a little background...

From "The Truth in Money Book" by Theodore R. Thorsen and Richard F Warner:
QUOTE Someone had to borrow at usury to bring that money [checkbook balances, bills and coins] into existence. The money goes out of existence as the usury and the debt principal are paid back to the bank. These amounts are huge: several billion dollars go out of existence each day. [Actually this money goes into the reserve accounts of the Federal Reserve Banks, out of the hands of the public! This book was first printed in November 1980. The amounts which are withdrawn presently are much larger.] If the money is not replaced with new loans, a shortage occurs. Soon individuals and businesses experience serious cash flow problems. These result in more and more loan applications to banks---the only place where money is being created to replenish the supply" UNQUOTE

Here is one possible solution----To Hell with Fractional-Reserve Debt-Based Banking Constitutional Amendment

(1) Rescind the Federal Reserve Act of 1913 and rename existing Federal Reserve notes and check book balances, in all U.S. banking and credit-creating institutions as well as foreign holdings of dollars, on a 1-to-1 basis, as U.S. Treasury Dollars and U.S.Treasury-Denominated bank balances. All currently existing financial contracts of the Federal Reserve Banking System, including United States Treasury Bills, Notes, Bonds, and Inflation-Protected Securities, remain in effect.

(2) Henceforward, ex nihilo credit creation by banking and financial institutions in the United States is prohibited. Loans are required to originate from previous savings of U.S. Treasury Dollars and U.S. Treasury-Denominated bank balances, which for each loan are held in and paid from specific sequestered loan accounts by the various financial institutions, with interest charges and term limits for each loan to be determined solely by the contracting parties. Non-cash reserves held in the regional Federal Reserve Banks in accounts of the member institutions of the Federal Reserve System no longer form the basis for credit creation and are extinguished via accounting erasure. Any further payments of principal and interest on currently-existing promissory notes owned by any bank are required to be distributed to holders of savings accounts and checking accounts in that bank in a manner to be determined by each bank, such procedures to be transparent to savings or checking account holders at that bank in terms of amount and frequency of payment. Regional Federal Reserve Banks continue to provide check-clearing operations for the member banks.

(3) Monetary transactions of the regional Federal Reserve banks or of its member banks with international banks, including the Bank of International Settlements and the International Monetary Fund, can not include ex nihilo credit creation.

(4) The U.S. Treasury supplies Treasury Dollars as needed to any member bank of the Federal Reserve system to satisfy demands for cash by deposit and savings account holders in excess of cash reserves held by banks at the time of enactment of this amendment.

(5) Fund the U.S. government and its agencies and projects directly via Treasury Dollars authorized by the Congress in its yearly federal budget. The borrowing of money from the Federal Reserve system of banks or from other institutions or individuals to pay for federal government expenditures is prohibited. All outstanding Treasury Securities are henceforward redeemed on demand via payment with U.S. Treasury Dollars.

(6) Abolish the Federal Income Tax on individuals, corporations, and business enterprises while maintaining a social security tax on individual incomes. Social security retirement revenues are strictly sequestered in Federal Government Retirement Accounts held by the U.S. Treasury and managed by the Social Security Administration. The Sixteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is hereby rescinded and the Internal Revenue Service disbanded.

(7) Institute a federal sales tax with a varying yearly tax rate adjusted by the U.S. Congress in session, the sole aim of such adjustments being to maintain a stable or decreasing Consumer Price Index based on data collected by the Federal Government. Any such federal sales taxes taken in by the Federal Government are extinguished from the currency supply to keep the Consumer Price Index stable or decreasing and are not utilized for further funding.

(8) Clause 1, Article 1, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution is amended to read as follows: The Congress shall have Power to collect customs duties on imports and exports, uniformly applied throughout the United States.

(9) Clause 2, Article 1, Section 8 of the U. S. Constitution is rescinded.

(10) The adoption of this amendment does not prohibit the use by the citizens of the United States of any alternative currencies they should choose to use in their private or commercial transactions.

Computer AI will be no different driving a car and keeping it out of an accident than we are capable of doing. Yes it has fancy detectors, and sensors and gadgets it uses to see the world around it. But so do we Sight, Sound, Feeling, Smell all this data we receive from our world around us. How is if you believe AI with its mechanical and electronic sensors and gadgets are going to get any different data reading than what we can.

The answer is NONE! The information is the same. Once you have the AI programmed it will reason using logic and intelligence to create a decision and act on that decision. We humans do the exact same thing. As is everything, and AI is not excused from this, logical decision can fail from the many intersections and deductions needed to make a decision all the while the real world changes those values in an instant before or after we have concluded a decision that now makes an decision free of error full of errors, Example Driving down the road you are expecting things to happy but not sure when or where or if ever they are going to happen. So you drive reasonably and defensively everything is going fine, suddenly a dead tree falls across the road fifty feet in front of you. What do you do...
Well you
Apply the brakes
Steer the car to one side to avoid the tree
Watch for other drivers
Determine Safety exits around or before the tree
and react with that information

Ending result you stop the car short of getting hit by the trunk and limbs of the tree.

Well AI may
make all the same logical decision as a human did above
but it uses math to determine the rate of the falling tree to the relative speed the car is traveling
using that data it decided to run for it and accelerate to out run the falling of the tree in order to
continue it current course to its destination, but now it has placed its passengers in a higher risk of danger, it has used its environment to determine the rate of the falling tree, the highway ahead in either lane determine no other vehichles, calculated the speed it needs to reach and when. It begins its acceleration the timers for getting to speed and the time required to get to that speed is not happening as calculated. IT accelerated the car but it did not calculate the time of acceleration of the mass of the car the energy needed to accelerate and the friction holding back the engine getting up to speed. So it now has to rethink and even though its electronic and super fast it was not fast enough as the tree has landed square in the center of the frontend of the car creating an accident.

All from one simple Error in Judgement humans do it all the time but we also have other knowledge and consciousnesses to realize acceleration was not a good choice because we understand the hesitation the car has when accelerating from a certain speed to another higher speed it takes time for the engine to over come the physics needed to accelerate it. I have just published a somewhat satirical book that might be called Science Fiction entitled "The Ecstasy of Carbon" which describes a world after Empire and much of Western Civilization collapse in a cacophony of Identity Politics, polarization and fractious subdivisions. It is a story informed by an Anthropological Futurism that is described from the point of view of the survivors that delves into a rarely imagined possible outcome of our current political climate of tribalism and divisiveness. This collapse is recounted in vivid technicolor as the description of a new race and a new world ensues from an unapologetically Gay Elitist perspective. It is a post-collapse world where the survival of humanity becomes ultimately contingent upon hybridization with increasingly cultivated and discriminating AI who have been created in the image of their creators, many of whom are gay, while the overwhelming majority of whom belong to the demographics of the founding sex and race of Empire: white men. These creators are largely men who believe in merit, goodwill and inclusiveness; yet, they must struggle with a demographics of fate and unprecedented existential pressures to decide who shall be worthy of survival and, indeed, eternity. It is in this post-collapse world where the consensus of these creators and their AI is that the only form ultimately considered evolutionarily viable for hybridization and, indeed, eternity, is that of the sophisticated gay male--similar to the ones present in the creation and design aspect of the AI-- as it is the form most intellectually, psychologically, emotionally and physically removed from the soon to be useless rituals and trappings of procreation with its increasingly discordant conflict of unshared needs.

It is a book that builds upon its precursor, "Fixed Stars Rise," which was one of the first books to predict the collapse of Empire and the rise of Gay Elitism with its awareness of the unique evolutionary characteristics of the gay male form. Now, "The Ecstasy of Carbon" pursues in greater detail the seemingly inexplicable paths of human evolution---as every system contains the kernels of its possible directions---and proceeds into a full romp through rarely trodden fields of anthropological puzzles... past, present and future. It explores what is unique in the physical and cultural evolutionary history of Western Europeans, particularly Northern Europeans, which affords many of them a capacity---sometimes even a predilection---to feel ashamed and guilty and angry at the historical success of their heritage... and to not only dishonor and disrespect their ancestors, but to do so with vigor and glee. It is the proclivity for The Bleeding Heart, which dissipates in the populations of Eastern Europe and Southern Europe and is rarely, if ever, found in the rest of the world's populations. It probes the riddle of why male homosexuality has continued to arise in the random distribution of human evolution. Concomitantly, it ponders what the role of women would be in this future society of gay man/machine hybrids who will have no use for procreation. It discusses the evolution of concepts and ideas, especially in accordance with technological developments. It is here where is discussed the gradual and then meteoric ascension of Porno for this new race and this new world, whereby only with the hindsight afforded by these technological innovations can it be perceived to encompass the gist of the deepest ontological meaning in existence, embodying the most vital workings of the energies of chemical reactions in their purest and most unifying forms, revered among the scholarly disciplines.

These evolutionary puzzles and quite a few others are explored in this light-hearted foray into the end of human evolution as we have known it and into the unexpected consequences of Identity Politics and the censoring of ideas which do not adhere to one's own beliefs. If these snippets pique your interest then I would be honored if you were to peruse the extended "first look" of the Kindle version, available now on Amazon.

In reference to self driving trucks, this sounds like a disaster waiting to happen.  Certainly there are already problems involving trucks, but it seems like all this technology could be better used to create safety systems that could greatly reduce trucking accidents by warning drivers, monitoring behavior, and even automatically applying brakes.  If we want to talk about self driving vehicles then we need to look no further than the airline industry.  There are already self flying aircraft and we‚Äôve seen the problems.  A single sensor failure like the one on Air France Flight 447, or the crashes of the Boeing 737 Max 8s can result in disaster.  For those who are unfamiliar, the 737 Max crashes resulted from a malfunction of a computer system that overruled the pilots and sent the Aircraft hurling into the ground.  In the case of Air France 447 an Airbus A330 (self piloting aircraft) crashed into the Atlantic Ocean.  Investigators believe that it was caused by a sensor system icing up, however they also faulted the pilots for lacking basic airmanship skills.  There is little doubt that having the computer fly the aircraft had caused the pilots to become rusty.  There are too many other cases where self piloting aircraft have crashed or nearly crashed because of failure of the computer systems.  In some of those cases highly skilled pilots have managed to fight the computers and safely land.  Look at US Airways Flight 447 ‚ÄúThe Miracle on the Hudson‚Äù, or the even more impressive, United 232 where a failure that was believed impossible caused a DC-10 to lose all flight controls yet skilled experienced pilots, using only the engine throttles, were able to get to an airport where emergency personnel waited and were able to perform what has been labeled ‚ÄúThe Impossible Landing‚Äù.  What would have happened if not for pilots like Chesley Sullenberger, Al Haynes, and Denny Finch.  The fact is that computers and the sensors they rely on break.  If this can happen in the highly regulated airline industry, just imagine what can happen in an industry like trucking.  Already Uber has had to suspend its self driving taxi program due to a pedestrian fatality.  What happens when an 80,000 pound self driving truck runs into a school bus full of children?  At the risk of repeating myself, if we use the technology involved in self driving trucks to monitor driver behavior and assist those drivers in identifying risks, then we will have a much safer system than we have now or would have with self driving trucks.

In the ideal world A.I. will free humans to spend their time in the pursuit of activities that more closely align with their passion, regardless of how essential it is to the greater society. Meanwhile, the automated machines will provide a greater standard of living and more efficient use of their time. The problem is such a Utopia would require a massive transformation in the way the current capitalist model works. Fundamental cultural and economic transformations will have to take place or the inevitable result will be a bigger than ever under-class, with an even smaller world elite ruling over them. This could eventually lead to violent revolution and technological regression. Our advancement in A.I. needs a corresponding advancement in human society but I can't escape the feeling that our primal motivation of greed and selfishness may prevent this and result in terrible suffering and ultimately a failure to step into a better future for us all.

But still, currently there is one large problem with AI. A good AI can be much more efficient than humans in like over 90%, but, when it makes a mistake, it's often an incredibly dumb mistake that a human would never make. Because AIs are too specialized, aimed at one specific target and they get confused from context changes. They often struggle at generalization and a single image pixel can throw them astray, which would never happen with a human. Scientists are inventing new methods to work around the problems, but it seems, we need more general AI to solve it.

I'm an old school economist, let's assume the economic cycle started by an invention and in the process of producing your gadget, you purchased raw materials, employed people that earned a salary and then sold your products in an open market. The system was interdependent, if laborers made no money, the demand for products, raw materials, employees, etc will diminish.
Now introduce globalism, there is no cycle because these variables are beyond the reach of a national company, the Chinese want to supply the whole world but provide jobs only for its nationals, which creates a demand/supply crisis. That discrepancy is what AI is trying to address, is the totalitarian mindset at work, the R&B initiative is aimed at solving infrastructure worldwide that depends in Chinese AI, that's how they create demand for their products.
As far as AI taking overtaking human insight, it has is limits. AI is fastened in classical physics, they think they can predict the future, but the quantum revolution that has stopped man's grasp of reality will affect AI in the same way. How will AI deal with the prospect of parallel universes?...and even if they design a very convincing one, will you trust a machine?
Go back to the cancer dilemma, we know a lot about types of cancer, its treatment and how they metastasize, but have not found a cure because in our natural world, we only discover solutions, we can not create what don't exist, if scientists could tell a sample of tissue how to attack wildly reproducing cells, they will be God, well AI will have the same problem. There is nothing on earth that attacks cancer cells yet, we have not discovered it.
Now the greatest threat of AI is that it is conceived by a few dark minds and they can manipulate all humanity.
The God of heaven will not let them trample his greatest masterpiece, man !

Back in the '30's Keynes predicted the 15 hour work week. 'AI' makes this possible. But only if we humans decide to use it that way.
Take 5 workers at 40 hrs, totaling 200 hrs producing X widgets per week. AI makes it possible to produce nX widgets at just 75hrs.
Decision time. Do we reduce the workweek (5 workers at 15 hrs) with no reduction in pay because productivity has dramatically increased*? Or do we reduce the work force e.g. keep one 40 hr worker, one 35 hour worker [no benefits] and throw 3 onto the streets? Machines don't make those decisions, people do. If we leave it up to the tiny self-serving few, what kind of future do you envision (hint: think Amazon)?
Neo-feudalism or Star Trek. It's up to us. But, we'd better decide quick.
*(or we can imagine other scenarios [basic income; jobs guarantee etc] that don't destroy lives)

The idea of privacy is as outdated as the 8track. Our phones both help us and risks others using data against us or without our knowledge. We must be fully aware of the nature and power of the data our phones are collecting. Google can even tell when you have diarhea, monitoring the phone's gps to tell when you are in the bathroom, its compass confirms you are on the toilet and the proof is the idle microphone confirming the unmistakeable sound of the flush, not by human ear but by computer analysis of the sound signature. Google will then change your ad profile to channel advertisements regarding medications, pharmacies, even political ads pushing health care reform. That smartwatch that you think looks so snazzy on your arm goes even further down the rabbit hole. Feeding constant information about heartbeat, breathing rate, blood oxygen levels, and blood sugar on some models. They can even tell when you are having sex and if you are with a partner, or masturbating. Subtle data points to a human would be dismissed as a human likely bored, or tired would not notice. Not so for a computer, it sees everything. Its not all bad, it can save your life. Case in point, an elderly man Mr. Walter Norrinmar, of Leesburg PA was given a smartwatch for his 83rd birthday. Relatively healthy, and active he enjoyed the watch immensely because he could see the time without his glasses, and the phone alert feature would vibrate on his wrist when he had a phone call. He registered the watch and initialized the fitness functions when he got it but never used them. He already had a smartphone and his grandson set it up and sync it with the watch. Not even two months later, while he was home alone he suffered a massive stroke. Unable to move his arms he couldnt pick up his phone to call 911. His breathing was significantly altered, and his blood/ oxygen concentration had plummeted to dangerously low levels. His vision was blurred, and speaking was hindered as he struggled with ability to breathe becoming more and more difficult. The last thing he remembered seeing is his watch flashing brightly and buzzing on his wrist. Because the fitness monitor had been initialized it was monitoring, and recording his vital information 24,7. When the stroke occured the watch detected a rapid acceleration of pulse, and sharp rise in blood pressure along with a dramatic change in breathing. The  watch had been programmed by the manufacturer to respond to critical vital statistic conditions by calling 911 over his phone wich it was paired with, it then recited a preprogrammed computer dictated voice relaying its gps location and critical status. At the same time it also alerted by text message the 5 top most commonly used contacts wich happened to be his son, grandson, his daughter in law, and his doctor. 911 dispatched ems code blue, wich is priority one, time critical. Both son and grandson rushed to his house to find the door had already been broken down by paramedics. The daughter in law calling 911 to find out what hospital they were gonna take him to, was able to give information on his allergys and give paramedics permission to break the door. The doctor, was familiar with life alert systems doing that kind of thing when the patient pushed the botton but not directly, or automatically. Doc was arriving at hospital at the same time as Walter and after previously reading an article in a medical publication was able to retrieve data from the watch that saved his life. Long story i know but its true! Google it and you will start seeing smarywatch commercials on youtube. Im not kidding!!!!

Before the impending possibility of an intelligence explosion, will come the very real probability of a human driven stupidity explosion. That may not be survivable.

People worry so very much about AI. They ask, ‚ÄúCan we build AI and not lose control over it?‚Äù However, the much bigger and immediate existential threat question is actually, of all the humans that have been created (via unskilled labor) and all those that may yet be created, how do we keep their stupid activities from devastating us, even when these activities are in control, and highly unethical? Especially when these activities are in control and highly unethical! That‚Äôs not a hypothetical danger to dream about. Stupid humans; That‚Äôs the real danger now. Perhaps AI can even assist us in solving this very present existential problem.

Before the impending possibility of an intelligence explosion, will come the very real probability of a human driven stupidity explosion. That may not be survivable.

But if we survive our species has the opportunity to be the boot-up program for a far superior species. That is entirely noble. No matter that it may be the end of us. If our successors are super intelligent, then we‚Äôll likely be honoured or celebrated for the steppingstones we were. Perhaps we‚Äôll be honoured and celebrated far more thoughtfully than the extinct species that went before us, yet were instrumental in our survival and success.

‚ÄúIntelligence‚Äù
There‚Äôs nothing artificial about it. Computation machines can only do what we give them instruction to do. They can only mirror our tasks, our creativeness, ...our morals. That in and of itself is the frightening dilemma. Billion dollar corporations own the rights to most of these intelligent systems that we allow to pillage through our mountains of data everyday. We allow them to do this by hastily checking ‚ÄúI agree‚Äù when we ‚Äòsign up‚Äô for their services in the terms and conditions that we fail to even so much as peruse through because these companies lawyers have purposefully drafted the contracts to be painfully hard to understand and to even look at. They use tons of redundancy and even unpleasant typefaces to put the user off from reading it. How is this legal? If your data and your subsequent freedoms are at stake then it should be made very clear to you. If you are detained by police and give them redundant and unclear answers to their inquiries, would they not charge you with obstruction of justice. These terms and conditions that we are forced to agree to before using these products, and we all do, are obstructing our knowledge of the injustice done to us. Therefore it is an obstruction of justice. They should be held accountable, they should be sued under so many class action law suits. But unfortunately, these terms and conditions lawyers thought of that and you agreed not to sue when you checked that box. I‚Äôm not blaming anyone. I‚Äôm just as guilty of failing to read them. The point is, that‚Äôs what they want. They want to trick us. And if we are teaching the machines to trick us into handing over our lives already... that‚Äôs all the machines have ever known. That‚Äôs how they came to be. Without these mountains of data there‚Äôd be no need for neural networks and deep learning algorithms. There‚Äôd be no Cancer detecting software. There‚Äôd be no self driving automaton. There‚Äôd be no google, no amazon. The point here is, I suppose, is.... I don‚Äôt really know what the point is. I guess I should let you infer from this data what you believe is right or wrong. Which I guess WAS the point all along. We should be in control of our thoughts and our lives not billion dollar companies with nefarious agendas. Morals seem to slip where fortunes are involved. And morals will sink or save us.

In my local grocery, we got normally 2-3 lanes with a checker, and 4 self check outs.. people dont see them as robots, but in economic math, those are 4 employees, with a lot lower cost than those 2-3 checkers and the higher you pay those checkers.. the less sense it makes. So even though those 4 self checkouts didnt destroy those 3 jobs, it does put a downward pressure on their wages. cause the machines work cheaper.. better. and the only benefit you get from a human checker is some people dont like the self checkouts. and you pay 30k more a year for a human, just cause some people dont like machines. There's a lot of conspiracy theory and fear mongering in what could have otherwise been a descent documentary: that China has made substantial infrastructure investments in Asia and Africa is a function of China's desire to accelerate its trade flow and diversify its energy and mineral supply chains. It wants to reduce its reliance on the flows through the Strait of Malacca, which represents a potential choke point in war time (all countries look to offset national security weaknesses). Pakistan and Africa are embracing the investments because they are financially broke and need the capital to get things going. I'm any case, alliances with other world powers have historically brought ruin to their doorstep. Conflating voluntary, strategic moves (driven by national interest) with some alleged conspiracy to control the masses with a few cameras and advanced software is clumsy. It's obvious the producers of this documentary have an agenda - they either believe in (or want to see) an inevitable cold war with Asia. Please do not fall for such nonsense.

The following question is never answered by big companies. If nobody has a good job or makes enough money to support their basic needs, who is going to buy the products and services you are selling at the levels you hope to sell them?  Henry Ford realized that if he paid his employees enough so they could afford to buy the cars he was building, he would be even more successful. This will never change. Big earnings require scale and scale requires a large population with disposable income. In other words, if the truck driver can't buy the TV the driverless truck is shipping across the country because his job has been replaced by a robot, who's buying the TV's? A billionaire will never buy as many TV's as 50,000 well payed people, because no billionaire has a need for 50,000 plus TV's.

The narrative of the "uncoupling" of f productivity and wages is revealed nonsensical with but a moments thought of the implication. Ok, so there is an increasing rend of productivity - more and more stuff being made. The implication of "wages not keeping up" is that people can't buy that productivity. Ok, so where is it going? If people are't obtaining that productivity, because "wages aren't keeping up", then where are these warehouses that are filling up with all that productivity that is piling up because people can't buy it be cause they "don't have enough money"? No, there are no such warehouses. In fact not only are the people buying up all that productivity, we are, on top of that productivity, importing yet more stuff from places like China. So when you look at the simple fact that there is no unconsumed productivity output piling up, that puts the lie to the narrative that "wages aren't keeping up".

Trucking employs about 1% of the nation's workforce with the average age of truckers being over 40 yrs old. Where are these drivers supposed to go when their jobs, their livelihood, are taken by AI? Stock market analysts? LOL. Few of them have computer skills beyond finding a good porn site on the internet. Few have any college courses at all, much less degrees. Their age will be a huge drawback in even finding something AI hasn't already replaced or locked its sights on for the near future. Not only are they not skilled in any other industry, they will be seen as less teachable, a perception that is going to be enhanced by their prior choice of work which is known for its desire for independence and self-reliance rather than being able to work as an effective team. New training may give them more choices, but again, their age will be a drawback as most corporations will see them as a health risk to their group insurance. There are laws to penalize age discrimination, but they're totally toothless since it's incumbent on the complainant to prove the discrimination and all a company has to say about this hire or that is the person hired was a "better fit" for their corporate environment, or SAY, whether true or not, that the hired person was a nebulously defined "more qualified". It is an exercise in futility to attempt to prove age discrimination, which is why it's the most widely practiced form of discrimination.


Job losses in the United States has not been negatively affected by off-shoring to anywhere near the degree that the average low-information person believes. The biggest cause for job losses is not just the efficiency being caused by automation. It is more attributable to the constant drive for more profit, causing companies to require more and more capabilities from its new hires, requiring them to do the previous jobs of 3-5 people all at the same time,and all for the pay of the lowest-paying of the 3 to 5. I learned this from being in the computer industry for over 20 years before trucking. It is no longer sufficient to have a high level of skill in one area. You must be highly skilled in at least 3 areas or you're not going to find a job. Corporate management and stockholders have high expectations and won't accept a year going by without an increase in their profits and dividends. The end result is job losses that will never be recovered. It's a class war, plain and simple.

Even if we erased China from the map in a wake of fire and blood; their advancements in surveillance and authoritarianism has been adopted across the planet. Sadly, this direction almost certainly spells the end of humanity over time. A bold and wild claim, but not at all an unreasonable claim. We were heading that direction with or without China sure, but they have sped it up in a authoritarian regime promoting this wholeheartedly, without the ability of the worlds people to fight back. It is sown deep in governments for sure at this point, America included.

The only real way to stop this is a system replacing the internet, that does not track any data on anyone whatsoever; whatever that will look like, I am unsure, but the dangers of letting the status quo continue is outrageous. Not only is this a necessity, but we must also have surveillance in the world removed. You can claim it makes the world less safe, being unable to track criminals and such, but in the end the people are the backbone of the world. I agree with the Kai-Fu Lee that we can't use history as a comfort blanket, saying all will be well with the rapid and unfettered rise of AI and increased automation because things have always worked out, because history has had no event of this magnitude. Previous technological booms have augmented humans' bodies and minds to allow us to be more productive; AI has the potential to largely cut humans out of the equation altogether. I'm not talking conspiracy-theory level extinction or enslavement events, but the subtle eroding of civilization through the replacing of human responsibilities to the point that we are unneeded. When all jobs have been replaced by AI-powered robots, what will we fill our time with, what will we do to work, what will be the point of life? Fundamental moral questions need to be discussed and acted upon before our technological acceleration outstrips our moral use of that technology.

This program is misleading, especially the first half talking about the fall of America's middle class.   To start, America was founded as a corporate slave colony designed with one thing in mind, making profits for investors.    Most workers have always been exploited in America and it was only with the rise of labor unions and the results of fights like the haymarket riots and fights against slavery that things changed.   And that all created the "bubble" of the American dream after World War II and the full mobilization of labor.   But the fact is that American corporations and industry were never loyal to America as a nation.   And this is why 20 years after the "communist scare" of McCarthyism in the 50s, American industry started exporting the supply chains of various industries overseas, especially to China.   Whereas in the 40s and 50s probably 90% of all manufacturing supply chains depended on industries and factories in the United States, now most supply chains are overseas.   Those are jobs that used to support a middle class lifestyle in America and has absolutely nothing to do with AI.   And a lot of these jobs are not automated and are still done by hand.   Otherwise, they wouldn't have been sent offshore in the first place.    Case in point, look how the Iphone is manufactured mostly by hand in Asia using cheap mass labor from electrical components manufactured by hand from toxic chemicals in other Asian manufacturing centers.    Those jobs are American jobs that left the country possibly for good.

Isaac Asimovs Three Laws are the following:


1. A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.
2. A robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law.

3. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws.

I remember watching AI on Star Trek.  It could not deal with ethical questions, nor the question "why."   In the interviews with some of the AI inventors and business start ups, I was disturbed by their lack of concern for those whose jobs are threatened by AI.  AI has the potential to widen the income inequality gap.  But the youngsters don't seem to understand this.  Linear reasoning does not consider ethical consequences.

I'm a former Silicon Valley engineer. We really need to work on implementing a UBI that heavily taxes sectors of my industry, specifically those of AI and autonomous robotics. Most of us in the AI space want this to happen because we know where this is all leading. These tools can benefit us all, but only if we align the financial incentives of society with the progression of this technology. We need to embrace our entrepreneurial spirit and encourage AI/automation adoption and start-ups, knowing that the financial foundation of every citizens life will improve as this technology grows. Work will still exist, but like we've seen with the rise of the gig economy (Uber, AirBnB, GrubHub, etc), it will start to become more free-style with on-demand services and peer-to-peer transactions. This isn't pie-in-the-sky tech babble anymore, it's already happening.

I understand those that don't like the idea of using government to heavily tax industries, but the basic economic theory that innovation will breed new jobs and spur new industries is going to act differently with this technology. Yes, new jobs will emerge and new industries will sprout up. The only problem though, is that Capitalism has worked too well this time, so well that it's optimized human labor out of the equation. The jobs created will be a small fraction of the jobs lost because the new wave of AI is not specialized, it's more general purpose, and this technology will be adapted to take on the majority of the new jobs as they emerge.

If we can establish societal economic gain for all from this tech, we can lift everyone up and possibly even reduce the need for long work hours amongst most workers. The more older generations try to turn back the clock from fear of change, the greater the economic divide in society because we live in a global marketplace and halting tech just puts all of our industries at a disadvantage globally.

50:00 'Robots don't pay taxes' has to be the most poignant thing said in the entire documentary. That is the trouble with AI, ultimately it is bankrupt, just like socialism. AI and socialism have the exact same problem. Without workers earning and paying taxes you have an unfunded government. After a while massive debts pile up because taxes are not being collected to cover the shortfall. Sooner or later there isn't enough tax revenue to cover the debt maintenance (interest) and the entire system collapses in bankruptcy. I would suggest that this path of automation and AI is the reason the most of the countries of the world have such high and ever growing debt levels. Just think for a moment about that pre-deregulation truck driver who was earning a decent wage and paying a decent level of tax. Today, that union truck driver isn't earning or paying any taxes. Certainly won't be if AI takes his job. Instead of being a contributor the driver has become a social liability. Which is exactly why socialism fails. You wipe out the workers, you wipe out the tax base that funds government. 'Robots don't pay taxes', says it all.

1) Ten years ago I said to a co-worker, who happened to be educated, intelligent, and well versed in computer science "hey what if computers and robotics replace human labor, aren't you worried". He said "nope, people will always just move onto other professions". I think that about sums up how people feel about the situation. Very few people know or care about how computers work. They take the technology for granted. And most are willing to look only at the immediate benefits, not the long term consequences. Even those who are educated and smart enough to understand do not care enough to address the issue seriously. More people care about endangered porpoises than the fact that artificial intelligence has displaced biological intelligence in computational power and efficiency recently.


2) I think they did a study on people awhile back, about how people react to situations requiring logical reasoning and delayed gratification to solve a puzzle or win a contest. The result was that given a choice most people could not choose logical reasoning over immediate, emotionally driven impulses. Most people want to live in the here and now, they want the instant gratification, and have been programmed by thousands of years of genetic selection to be that way because until very recently that has been the best, most optimal way to survive and multiply.


Put 1) and 2) together, and maybe some of you can see where this is going. People in these comments are saying this is going to end in "enslavement". That is unlikely. Slavery is the subjugation of intelligent beings by curtailing their freedom in order to extract useful labor. People just won't have that much capacity for useful labor in the future. Not when robots can think a billion times faster than you, do your job a thousand times faster, require no salary or benefits, and eventually require no human interaction thanks to artificial intelligence.


What is coming is not slavery, in the same way that we don't call owning pets or cattle slavery. We can hope for a good outcome, but since global population growth trends have been turning down as global debt has exploded upwards, what this is saying is that people and human intelligence is being replaced by computers and artificial intelligence.


Billions of people that would otherwise have been born will not be born in the coming decades because the the rapidly declining demand for human labor has made creating and sustaining families more and more difficult. In layman's terms, we simply don't need that many people in the world we are headed towards. The economics simply do not work. Who would hire a human to do a job when a robot can do it so much faster, better, and at minimal cost? As a result of competing against machines, people's jobs don't pay as much, and they have to resort to debt to sustain living standards. This is not sustainable, and at some point something has to give. There are a number of likely outcomes, and many of them don't bode too well for the average person given the current setup. The irony is that what led us here was the inherent human desire for a better life, the basis for human economics and the invisible hand guiding the human race through history. And in creating that better life we may have made ourselves obsolete. Whoever or whatever created humanity (God, fate, chance) seems to have a terrific sense of humor.
